I came here with high hopes after hearing multiple friends rave about it. The food took over an hour and was room temperature at best, our waiter comes back in 20-30 minute intervals. We've been sat since 6:30 and have been waiting for our checks for another 30 minutes. I won't be coming here willingly any time in the future.

A very nifty place to visit while in Pittsburgh. We're vegan so our food choices were limited. But there was a veggie burger and the soft pretzels were vegan (without the cheese sauce). The pretzels were absolutely amazing. So soft and flavorful. My mouth is watering just thinking about them now. The inside part of restaurant gets very very loud, but you can go outside for a quiet place to talk. The restaurant and beer garden area is huge!  The beers can be ordered in a normal size or a ginormous mug that I needed 2 hands for.  They also have a variety of mule drinks that come in the copper mugs.  Their German beers are made on site. There's also a gift shop for souvenirs.
I got the Wurst meal of the month here....it lives up to the title for sure! Don't Forget to ask for real mustard.

A great place to go with large groups of people. Adequate bar food, decent beer, fun entertainment, attentive service. The history is interesting, but the presence of a gift shop adds to the off-putting feeling of fairly obvious American over-commercialization.
The food is always great as is the service. We go when the weather is nice enough to sit outside.

There was a large group of us that went to Hofbrauhaus a week ago.  I had been there a few different times during the week or on a Friday.  This was a Saturday night and they do not take reservations on Saturday nights.  We waited approxmately two hours to get seated (eight of us).    I thought the service was great.  Our waitress was very attentive, especially with the size of our group.  I enjoyed the food, beer, and environment in the bier garden as well.  It is a great place to go with a large group.  I would definately go back to Hofbrauhaus, just not on a Saturday night so I could avoid waiting a few hours!

Food is ok.  If I want traditional German I would go to Max's Allegheny Tavern.  That being said the beer is top notch.  The atmosphere is great.  It gives you the choice of being in a near authentic Bier Hall or a Ratskellar all in one restaurant.  Great place to go if you wanna have a fun time.

This place was great!!  We sat outside on the massive porch and enjoyed a few liters of beer.  The food is fantastic and the salad could feed a small army.  Will definitely come back when I am in the area.

Carbs aplenty...with a side of meat!  Tasty German food, but my favorite thing are the pretzels with the cheese sauce....love them!  This place has a few different dining atmospheres. There is the big hall, with long tables and communal benches where I have seen people dancing on the tables and singing along with the musician. There is also a more traditional dining room area. Then, there is an outdoor beer garden, which is pretty great when the weather is nice- umbrellas, a river view, and tables for both smaller and bigger groups, so it's a great place to bring a crowd. No worries about having 'everyone in your party present in order to be seated.' They are totally cool with people coming and going. The service is good. Even out in the beer garden, servers come by to check on you frequently, which is good if people keep coming and going from your big group....or if people decide they are hungry at different times.   Now, the beer....I'm more of a cocktail girl, but everyone here seems to enjoy the beer choices...and the sizes. They offer beers in the liter and half-liter size. There is something enjoyable about hefting a weighty 1L glass....this beer is no joke, though. Once, while passing through the indoor hall, someone vomited right in front of me. So, watch out for those liter beers. They pack a punch, and not everyone handles it well. One final note - the outfits the waitresses wear make me feel like a bad feminist for patronizing this place, but I do it anyway.

Good atmosphere but if you're looking to just experience the beer and the food I would suggest going earlier in the evening or at lunch time. It gets packed with a younger crowd at night, the music is pretty loud and they recycle the same 6 songs that college kids love to sing out loud when theyve been drinking. Also you always leave smelling like the food! The outdoor beer garden is great during warm months though because you can sit outside along the river and hear the people you are with. Good experience once in awhile but just be careful as to the time of day you go!

Went there twice for the lunch buffet - enjoyed it the first time; wasn't too happy after the second. The buffet is a great place to try German food in addition to the add-on starters (pancake was better than the pretzel) and dessert items (puff pastry was better than the streudel). Place was quite and the few who were there looked they were on a lunch break. The buffet table and utensils are outdated but very clean. Staff are usually friendly. Want too happy about paying for parking (street/deck) when most other restaurants validate parking for upto 2 hours). The soups on the buffet are a bit salty but AWESOME!

Decent traditional German food?  Check.  Delicious German beer?  Check.  Polka music?  Check!!!  Need I say more?  Probably not, but I'm going to anyway.  This place is really fun to visit with good buddies and to get a bit of a buzz.  Will the food knock your socks off?  Probably not especially, though it certainly isn't bad food.  Is the beer ground-breaking?  Not exactly, but it tastes good, fresh, cold, and comes in large and ridiculously large (always a good choice).  Are there many other places out there where you can drink and hear live polka music?  Very few!  Enjoy the atmosphere, have a sausage, and drink a beer.  You'll feel better after you do.

I was traveling for work this week and staying at a nearby hotel.  I wanted something different than "national chain" restaurant food but close by and the hotel front desk recommended Hofbrauhaus.  It proved to be an excellent recommendation.  The service at the resturant was quick and efficient from the front door all the way through paying the bill.  The German food that we had was delicious.  I had the house brewed Hefe Weizen and Sauerbraten and Apple Streudel for dessert.  I'd highly recommend this establishment.

This would have gotten a 4 because as great as it is, it's not the original ... and nothing beats the original.  They do, however, do a really really great job with this location.  It's definitely a solid, consistent 4.  The 5 comes from them finally introducing my all time favorite  German beer.  Kristalweizen.  If you've never had a Kristal, I'd highly recommend.  It's basically a Hefe that's been filtered.  Add a lemon and you have a great summer beer.  Drink that in the Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh Biergarten and you get 5 stars!!

The Hofbrauhaus is definitely a fun place to visit if you are in the area and love German culture. I went for dinner with my family on a Saturday, and it was only a few minute wait for a table outside. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable on the food and beer selection, and all food and drink came out quickly!   I ordered the hefeweizen to drink, and the hot brown for dinner. The beer is honestly pretty strong, so if you aren't a huge drinker, you may need to prepare yourself for a little buzz. The hot brown is usually the standard choice for me, because it is basically a potato pancake smothered in cheese. It's very good, but very rich.   There is usually a German band playing inside, so it is always a little too loud to converse with the people at your table, so I prefer to visit this establishment in the summer. This isn't somewhere I would want to go to every weekend, but it is nice to go and get a different experience like once or twice a year.

Came here after the Whiskey and Fine Spirits Festival...great idea. We wanted to sit inside and dance but it was packed so we sat outside. I was bummed at first because I wanted my out of town friends to experience the 'Haus for all its glory but outside was a lot of fun as well.   Fast Service. GREAT Beer. Its was a total sausage...wait...bratwurst fest (which I'm always OK with :-)

Having been to the real Hofbrauhaus in Munich I was excited to hear about this one in Pittsburgh.  We loved it.  The location is fantastic.  The beer was great accompanied by live polka music on a Saturday afternoon.  We tried the schnitzel which was perfect and the sauerkraut was lovely.

We went here after biking, which may have been a bad choice because the beers are ginormous! Let me tell you, I had trouble riding my bike back after just one... The beer itself was just standard, nothing special, but it seemed a little too easy to drink a beer the size of my head... so they have something going for them.   All we go to eat was pretzels, and they were good, but also nothing too special. I think that the important thing here is that nothing is too expensive, you can sit outside on the river, and the beers are as big as your head!

Not a bad place to go for an experience.  I don't know how often they have a band, but every time I've been there they have.  So it gets pretty loud in there.  It's not a place I'd want to go all the time, but it's fun every once in a while.  The food is ok.  It's German style obviously, and some of it isn't to my liking, but most of it's at least decent.  If you haven't been there, I'd definitely recommend at least trying it.  It's better with a big group of friends though, not as a date.

The is such a great fun place. Great environment, great music, great food. There isn't a bad item on the menu, great view when you're sitting outside. The service is phenomenal and it's very large and spacious.

This place has some of the best booze and food out there and an AMAZING high-energy atmosphere. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because the last 2 times I was in there, the hostess got my # wrong (too noisy) and we ended up waiting nearly 45 mins due to the text message notification not coming through. I recommend checking in on your own accord periodically to ensure you didn't get passed over by mistake! It'd be nice if we could all input our numbers ourselves.

I'm so glad it's finally summer so I can enjoy the patio here. I visited on a Wednesday for my monthly girls dinner. It was not crowded at all. The Beer Garden patio is seat yourself. It has tons of picnic table and bistro table seating as well as it's own bar area and a few high tops.   Service was a little slow for it being so empty. I ordered the Beer Cheese Chicken. It's a huge portion so be prepared. The dinner comes with two chicken breast, mashed potatoes and sautéed peppers and onions. I was really happy with it. The mashed potatoes are amazing!   They have three main beer selections from Hofbrauhaus and one monthly seasonal beer. They have additional craft beers on tap available on a menu in the bar area.    I can't wait to go back for happy hour this summer.

I like the set up and the high ceilings--really adds to the old German beer hall atmosphere. Hofbrauhaus really strives to set itself apart from the other restaurants in Pittsburgh and it definitely earns its gold star for being quite unique. I also really like the outside seating and the view of the river. Great location! I don't like beer in general so I didn't order their beer.   When it comes to the food and service, however, I thought it's a bit on the lacking side. Our waitress was rude and impatient. I'm not familiar with German food or language, so of course sifting through the menu took longer than wanted. The waitress got a bit snappy when I asked her to explain some items on the menu. I ended up ordering the Ofenfrischer Leberkase, which came with a slice of meatloaf, a fried egg on top and some German potatoes. The meatloaf straight up tasted like processed meat with the rubbery consistency of cheap hotdogs. The potatoes were okay and fried egg tasted like fried egg. I did not enjoy my meal.   Overall, I respect the effort and creative attempt to imitate a German beer hall. The rating I'm giving is a very reluctant 3 for the concept. When it comes to the actual food, I don't think this place lives up to all the hype. I recommend Hofbrauhaus as a place to try for the experience, but definitely not a place I will return to satisfy my taste buds.

Great place to have a fun happy hour with friends! They had plenty of space to accommodate our large group and they let us know where we had to sit in order to get happy hour specials, when we originally sat ourselves in the wrong area. The happy hour deals here are great, their craft beer is only $3 and appetizers are half off. We ordered spinch dip, soft pretzles and cheese, and loaded fries. All of it tasted great and came out hot. I also really enjoyed their Original Lager beer, it had a crisp finish and wasn't too hoppy. The atmosphere here is one of the best parts. As you walk in, you feel like you have walked into a restaurant in Germany. There are large wooden tables, traditionally decorated rooms, and German entertainment. It's different from the typical restaurant/bar scene, which I found very refreshing and relaxing.

I don't come here for the food, although if you are a fan of German fare, you may come for the food. I come here for the beer (oh, delicious, yummy beer served in 1 liter mug) and the atmosphere, whether it is dance on the table to live music in the main hall or talking to friends on the balcony enjoying the view of the river.  It's a great place for a group of very loud people, not so much intimate dinners.

The beer is good, yet the food is underwhelming. My husband really loves the beer, a redeeming quality, but otherwise this place is a 2 star in my book. The service was slow when we went, the food didn't come fast or hot. I'll avoid my snobbery, but as someone that is of German descent, and has visited Germany, all of the food we tried is a sad representation. I know most people are interested in the experience, which Hofbrauhaus provides, but if you're interested in delicious German food, find a grandma and save yourself heartbreak.

I was here for a business dinner, and the company was great, the beer was great, but the food was just...okay. Maybe I'm not a fan of German food?  We had a private area on the side, as there was a huge group, and the dinner was buffet. The place was dimly lighted, like most restaurants, but this comes into play later....Nothing was marked, so I didn't know what anything was, except for the big fat pretzels. Them I knew! But they weren't super warm and there wasn't any mustard or cheese to dip them into. But they were decent. There was also brisket, then breaded cutlets of chicken (I think)-is that schnitzel?, some chicken in a mushroom sauce and a few other things, although I don't remember them because I didn't eat them.  The chicken cutlet was good, but could have used some sauce or something. The chicken in the mushroom sauce was deelish, and the brisket...was not brisket. Okay, remember I said it was dark in there? And I may have had a couple beers or so, but I took a bite of the brisket and was like. Woah. Not brisket. Not brisket. I had to ask my friend and she said "Of course not, you silly Texan, it's pickled sauerkraut!" So yeah. Not at all brisket.  We had apple strudel for dessert and that was good stuff! But the meal was just okay. Again, it may have been just me and my tastes.  I should be back here next year for the business meeting, and if they have dinner here again, of course I'll go, but I definitely won't get the "brisket"!
really great place to go out with friends. Love the large tables and outside seating. Good variety of food and yummy!

I have to be honest: Hofbrauhaus is just not my kind of place. The noise levels alone are enough reason for me to keep my distance. But, a friend really wanted to come here over the weekend to enjoy lots of German food and a side of beer, so I came with an open mind, good company, and an empty stomach.  As I mentioned, the noise level here is not kind to the ears - chatty patrons and (some admittedly fantastic) live performances alike make the volume almost overwhelming. This is not a place to come with a large group or anyone you want to have a real conversation with; you won't be able to hear anyone who's not next to or across from you. I'm admittedly not a fan of the seating here either, as the long tables and long benches ensure that getting up and down if you sit anywhere other than the very end of said tables and benches is not easy.  Once I'd sat down and committed myself to staying in that seat for the duration of the visit, it was time to decide what to order. My group started off with a pretty phenomenal appetizer. It was a sampler with multiple sauces (including some outstanding bier cheese), pretzels, fried prickles, sauerkraut balls, and potato pancakes (with applesauce on the side, of course!). Everything on this sampler was perfect and amazing and delightful. I'm not even usually a fan of sauerkraut, and I enjoyed the fried sauerkraut balls that came with this order.  On to the main courses; I opted for the Munich Market Salad because healthy eating and all that (I know, not exactly the place to go for the healthiest meal - had I mentioned a friend wanted to eat here?). And it was a fairly fancy salad - lettuce, strawberries, cranberries, pecans, pineapple, oranges, feta cheese...a pretty good combination, I'd say. Unfortunately, I also ordered the glazed salmon to top it. That extra salmon cost $4.99 - and as my picture proves, my salad came with the tiniest piece of salmon I've ever seen. I admit, that disappointed me, especially compared to the amount of meat on my friends' various orders. If decimal points were allowed, this surprise would definitely be reflected in my final star rating. But, decimal points are not allowed - and I primarily ordered a good salad, and a good salad was delivered to me. I actually intended to eat half of it and take some home for the next day...yeah, that didn't happen. I enjoyed it all right then and there.  So clearly my experience was up and down, but at the end of the night the downs weren't deal breakers. Like I said, I came with an open mind, and while Hofbrauhaus is not my kind of place, my experience and meal overall was just fine (although I certainly won't be ordering salmon on a salad again here). I admittedly won't become a regular patron any time soon, but I can appreciate why people like it and I won't tell people to avoid it entirely. If I'm asked to return again, I know I would enjoy exploring more of the menu. (And if nothing else, now I know that you can buy growlers at the bar here! Yes please!)

My first real trip to the Hofbrauhaus house. it was for a friend's birthday. It was an Saturday night, but it was completely packed. we had to wait outside for about 35 minutes. There was plenty of outdoor seating, so it wasn't bad at all.  we finally got seated and it took a few minutes to get ordered but I expected that since it was packed. Every seat was taken. I had some wine because I'm really not much of a beer person.  The wine was super delicious.   The food was really good. I know had spinach dip. My boyfriend had schnitzel and he loved it.   The experience is where the 4 star comes in people dancing on tables and singing covers of songs. It's really fun and definitely worth the trip at least once.

Excellent food. I've wanted to try this place for a long time and I finally was traveling on my own and got to come over. It's Labor Day so it wasn't crowded but I sat at the bar anyway. Order pork schnitzel and it was fabulous. Got the bier cheese spaetzel on recommendation by the bartender and was glad I did. Fun place. Beer was fine about what I expected. I would definitely come back.

This place always disappoints.  The food, in general, is bland and uninteresting.  Some items, like the potato pancakes, cross all the way into being flavorless.  What about the beer, you ask?  It is no better than okay and often served at the wrong temperature.  More than once, I've received a glass of beer that was damned near room temperature...and no, not all the beers on their menu should be served that warm.. Even when served at the proper temperature, their beers are not remarkable.  They aren't even as good as Sam Adams, which I consider to be just over the line into being good.  With the growth of brew pubs in the region, there are about a jillion places that have better beer.  German restaurants are pretty sparse around here, I concede, but I'm not sure that is much of a reason to choose this place for dinner.  That brings me to the wurst part of going here. (See what I did there?)  IT'S REALLY REALLY NOISY!!!!!11!  There's generally some mook wrestling an accordion to its death and several caucasians of Chads fist bumping and bro-ing at the tops of their voices and the inevitable drunken Yinzers yinzing their lungs out.  N' at.
I came here for lunch. I ordered the lunch buffet.  It was only $11.99 and it had everything I wanted. Everything was amazingly delicious.

Beautiful sunny low humidity July evening in the Biergarten next to the river? Heavenly! What a great place - had no idea about this outdoor biergarten with the Hefe Weizen we fell in love with when we were over in Germany last year. Lots of long open tables with open seating and a few smaller tables for more intimate drinking and dining. Mehr Bitte!!!

Hofbrauhaus is one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh because it's a dining experience. There's live music, great beer and surprisingly good food.   You can't beat the atmosphere here. My favorite is sitting outside at the bier garden. The main dining hall inside is always bustling, and it's a lot of fun. My son loves to dance to the music in the front by the band, and it's so cute to watch. If you're coming on a weekend, come early before it gets super crazy and check in ahead of time on the no wait app.   You can't come here without getting the pretzels and bier cheese. The cheese is to die for! I love the hot brown, and basically anything on the menu with bier cheese, but the hot brown is a potato pancake with smoked turkey, ham and bacon on top, drizzled with bier cheese. What's not to love? And I'm not a beer drinker, but I love the hefe weizen. It's a light, sweet beer, and the only beer I'll drink.

Well-known for its beer, Hofbrauhaus was originated in Munich, Germany more than four centuries ago. Today, it's considered the world's most famous beer hall. Lucky for me, I don't have to go all the way to Germany... with only seven hours drive from NYC, I was able to experience the traditional Hofbrauhaus food and beer in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.   Hofbrauhaus indoor dining room features traditional decors with nightly live entertainment, whereas outdoor dining area provides fresh breeze and relaxing water view.  Must-try includes world famous freshly brewed biers (of course), Oktoberfest schweinshaxe, braised classic pork shank and potato pancake. Good eats and hearty meals! Can't wait to come here for Oktoberfest!

Slightly above average beer and slightly below average food. This place is more of an "experience" than just a place for food and drinks if you sit in the main hall. There will be people doing shots, a guy singing/playing the accordion, people getting up on the tables, etc. Next time I go back, I will consider sitting in one of the quieter areas or outside depending on my mood.

Ahhh German food. This place is the pub to be at if you're visiting Pittsburgh! On top of their phenomenal  selection of beer (and mug size) they make German food delectable! The haus is very welcoming, very authentic, and loads of fun. I definitely recommend the oktoberfest beer and any of their Schnitzel! Heck you might as well just join in the fun during the month of October! All of the appetizers they offer are quite tasty and fun to share. Group seating at the long wooden benches and tables with the occasional German toast that the whole place shouts together makes this one of my favorite places to go when I'm visiting Pittsburgh.

Three stars for a pretty good lunch at this restaurant. Decent service, decent atmosphere, no wait time for a group, decent price for a lunch buffet. Pretty good food. I would recommend it.   I imagine that if I came on a weekend for dinner and drinks that my enthusiasm would be greater! Overall, a good place to visit.

I was here Saturday for the first time . I have heard nothing but great things about this place so I had to try it out even though I am no huge fan of German food . The restaurant is huge with two big outdoor seating areas . I was  impressed with the fast friendly service . A great place for a large group . The food was very good as well .

I was apprehensive about how I thought our night would go.  We came for a 21st birthday dinner at 5:30, and didn't get seated til 7pm.  They do not take reservations and even though my husband called and talked to a manager who said they'd do their best to accommodate us, no one passed the word onto the evening manager, so our group of 21 sat waiting for 2 tables.  Once that was done, we all had a great time.  The waitress was sympathetic to our older folks sitting right in front of the 'band' and didn't mind repeating things two and three times to our group.  We got our beers / drinks quickly and really enjoyed the loud, chaotic atmosphere.  There were mostly families and large groups when we were there, I assume the crowd changes drastically after 9pm.  The food was good - no problem substituting spaetzle for potato salad (I find their kartoffel salat a bit too sweet).  I had the Jagerschnitzel which I thought was pretty good.  The potato pancakes were a little over-fried (according to some of our guests at the table).  I've had the wurst platters and they are pretty good.  All in all, if you're up for a loud, adventurous night and meeting total strangers, you'll enjoy the Hofbrauhaus.  We did a lot of singing, shot-skis and just had an all around fun time.

Wow, wow, wow! This place was SO good. I've known Hofbrauhaus for their beer but not for the food. Also, I'd never had German food before this. Although I'm sure authentic German food is best eaten in the homeland, this was a great preface to it! The atmosphere of the restaurant was great. At the Pittsburgh location, be sure to sit outside when the weather permits it. There's nothing like a nice breeze and view of the river. If you sit inside, you'll be sitting family style. When I was there, there was a piano playing on the stage where we witnessed the entire restaurant burst into singing "Sweet Caroline."  The schnitzel was moist and full of flavor. I don't really like cabbage, but the side was really delicious and flavorful! Get the pretzel and bier cheese for an appetizer! You won't regret it.   There's street parking throughout the shopping area, as well as a parking garage. However, if you're planning on indulging a bit, Lyft/Uber is a must.   Fan of good German bier? Drop by!

This place next to our stays and we decided to give it a try. The foods were pretty awesome!! They have plenty of outdoors sitting. Perfect spot for family group or kids since they have separate quieter dining areas. Def recommend it for people around the river areas.

I can only give the Hofbrauhaus 3 stars and that's a shame considering that it was a nice place with good food and a great atmosphere.  They lost 2 stars for their waitstaff.  We had no idea what we should be doing when we first went in because no one was at the host/hostess stand.  We walked into the bar area and sat down and were ignored by everyone staff member walking by.  I finally asked a waitress if we could get service. She said no, because we weren't officially seated. What?  Are you kidding me???  We got up and went to the host stand and the guy there was an idiot.  He said we can't just seat ourselves, as if that's what we wanted to do or something!  I just wanted someone to pay attention to us. Well guess what?  He sat us in the exact same room as where we originally sat, but in a different spot not far from the original table.  Now does this make sense??  The food was OK, but there's not much enjoyment you can get from the food when you've been aggravated for 20 minutes just to get seated in a fairly empty restaurant.  That's too bad.
Great beer  and food but cheesy set up... However very nice back patio... Overall a nice place!

Hofbrauhaus is the sort of place I would insist upon taking a Pittsburgh visitor or newcomer to, as it so perfectly encapsulates all that is good and bad about Pittsburgh dining/diners. The joint: a chain, though one that's certainly hard to one by. The fare: gut busting German, slathered in sauces and heavy on the meats. The beer: delicious, and served by the liter. The patrons: loud, and numerous, especially on the weekends at dinnertime and beyond. I always enjoy coming here, though we don't come here that often. Compared to the rest of the chain joints in this part of the South Side, I'd definitely call this one first choice--even if it's just for the people watching and a heavyweight Dunkel.

4.5 stars...  This is the sort of place you come for an experience.  With tall ceilings, long communal tables, and lots of warm wood work, this place feels like our imagined Bavaria. The live music simply added to the atmosphere.  The food was priced on the high end, but I don't think I've ever been to a German restaurant that wasn't. My coworker and I split a giant pretzel which was soft and warm, served with amazing cheese sauce and mustard. I ordered the Jaeger schnitzel and it did not disappoint. It was tender with a crisp, thin crust and the sauce was delicious. It was served with roasted cabbage and German potato salad. While I really enjoyed the cabbage, I wish I would have requested spaetzle instead of the potato salad.  The server was average. She answered our questions and took care of our basic needs, but seemed to be in a bad mood although she never directed it to us. I might be cranky too if I had to wear a German beer maid dress all night at work. Hah.  Go here if you want a fun dining experience!
Saturday's the tops  Drink a friend, dance with a beer  OANS ZWOA DREI! G'SUFFA!

Hell yeah loved this place, came here right around Oktoberfest had a liter of beer Farva styel, did a little Ziggy Zaki, and had a great time. The grounds are very spacious and green. Lots of picnic style tables inside and out side. Definitely my new place to go to when I'm in the Burg.  Oh yeah and amazing beer.

The overal experience is great! The place is loud and looks like a huge cafertia! Really interesting expeirence.  The portions are huge! Alcohol portions are huge...you can get samplers if you want for a smaller portion.  They have live band! And you see some crazy things :)  Also, they have alot of sourkraut and sausages!

This is the place you take your mom when she wants to drink.   Overall, Haufbrauhaus is an excellent night out on the South Side of Pittsburgh. This is typically where I pick when my friends want to get slizered on the South Side and I can't avoid it.   The beer is good the food is decent and the atmosphere is excellente.   Food The food is a bit overprice but the atmosphere covers for the extra dollars. I can't enter the door without ordering the standard pretzels and bier cheese.  The beer is also exactly what you're expecting. They'll let you try whatever you want but if you're going hug, get the big cup. Never disappoints and you look like a bad ass.   The Staff Staff is typically friendly and glad you came  The Ambience The ambience is really what makes this place. You can dance on the tables and chairs to the house band, and all are encourages! The young and old, no discrimination - everyone gets blasted and gets an uber home.

I have been to the original Hofbräuhaus in Munich several times and always enjoyed myself there. When I saw that Pittsburgh had a Hofbräuhaus, I had to give it a try.   I thought the decor and ambience was a fairly close replica of the original, though the Munich Hofbräuhaus has a full band, not just an accordion player, and is much more crowded and lively.   They serve beer by the liter or half liter just as in Germany, and the quality of the beer seemed to be the same as what you find in Germany. Many of the same menu items you see in Germany are in the menu, but there are also some American additions, or at least menu items I don't remember seeing on the menu in Munich when I was there. I had one of these, the chicken bourbon sandwich, which I really enjoyed. It had a sweet bourbon sauce and was tender and tasty.   I think they did a real good job at creating a restaurant that gives you as closely as possible a similar experience to what you would get in Germany.

So my review of the food may or may not really be accurate, considering that I'm a huge lightweight when it comes to beer. I had one stein's worth and... at that point everything tastes delicious to me.  I was visiting a friend who goes to school in Grove City and she said that the Hofbrauhaus was a must-visit place in Pittsburgh. My other friend and I got off the airplane from NYC at 9PM and the three of us headed straight for this place for some dinner and beer.  We went just when Storm Khan was rushing through, though I guess Pittsburgh was relatively safe. The parking was pretty far and the walk kind of sucked. What sucked more was by the time we got there and were pulling out our IDs, my friend from NY realized she didn't have her ID on her, so we had to walk back to the car. The bouncer laughed at us and led us in.  Oh jeez, I have never been to a crazier beer garden. People were screaming along to songs on the top of their lungs, dancing on benches and swinging their steins. We were really hungry, so we opted to sit in a booth so that we could also talk. Basically, whenever the band paused, we would squeeze as much conversation as we could before being overwhelmed by sound again. It seemed like everyone was having a great time. The general ambiance was really impressive!  The food and beers were great! We ordered the Hofbrauhaus Pretzels for our appetizers, and the three of us got the Jaegerschnitzel (me), the pork loin special, and Hofbrauhaus Wurstplatte. The Jaegershnitzel was DELICIOUS. Omg, it was like honestly the best breaded pork cutlet I have eaten in my life. It was very soft on the inside, yet the skin was crunchy and flavorful. The portions were pretty big too. The German potato salad was interesting (more like scalloped potatoes) and the pickled cabbage was delectable, even though I am not a fan of anything pickled. My friend's pork loin was tender and juicy. I'm always scared of pork loins because usually they get too dried out, but this one was good, along with the mashed potatoes! The Wurstplatte was interesting. There were three different types of sausages, which I do not remember what they are called. I like the white one the best because it was so soft, almost like a fish sausage. It wasn't sharp and salty like normal sausages.  The pretzels were very salty (waaaay too much rock pieces on them) and the cheese was salty as well, but I don't like pretzels in general so I didn't dock any points off since I have a bias against them anyway. I ordered a stein of the Hofbrau Premium Lager, which was light and delicious. I think I got tipsy so quickly because I hadn't eaten anything else that whole day to prepare myself for this place. My Pitt friend ordered the Hofbrau Weizen, which was a bit too banana-y for my tastes, though the other two insisted that it was the best beer they had ever had. It was good, but not my favorite.  In general this place is a great experience. If you like rowdy crowds, friendly waiters, and great German food, this place is for you!

This is no more an authentic beer hall than the Tiki Lounge is an authentic Polynesian hut.  But the inside atmosphere is fun and energetic, with people dancing on tables as the band plays polkaized versions of Neil Diamond songs.  It is very very loud, with open seating after 9pm on weekends, so don't expect to have any conversations.  The outside is more chill and is a nice spot to sit along the river.  That said, the two stars are strictly for atmosphere only.  After 30 minutes of sitting outside went by with no one taking our orders, we had to chase down a waitress.  The beers are not-so-good.  The wheat is the only decent beer in the lot.  Instead of beers, I'd order a shotski--four shot glasses attached to a ski so all drinkers are forced to take shots in unison...Any shot you can imagine.  As far as the food goes, if you're not getting a pretzel, you'll be disappointed.  That's the only great item on the menu.  The sauerkraut is just awful.    The doormen here take their jobs too seriously.  I was startled by two of them yelling "thief" at me after I walked out with my group of co-workers.  Everyone around stopped to stare.  After the doormen said people had been stealing glasses, I showed them my left-overs from dinner were the bugle in my handbag.  The funny part is that I was stone-sober and didn't even order a drink there, so had no glass to steal.  I would have been willing to forgive and forget, but I never got an apology.  So I docked a star for poor service.

2 Words:  Awesome Beer.  It had to be the best place in town to watch the Olympics that night.  The atmosphere was superb.  Everyone was singing along with the band while standing on there chairs (with beer in hand).  This experience has added Hofbrauhaus to my list of places to visit when I go to Munich.

It's the atmosphere that gets you.  The first few times you get caught up in the hype.  Once that dies off, you realize that you are just left with mediocre food and beer.  It can be a lot fun though with the right mix of people.

Came to Pittsburgh for a meeting this week and had dinner and beers at the Hofbrauhaus.  Great beers, loved the German stein option, the food was really good, the long tables and bier haus is fun.  Everyone at in my group seemed to enjoy their food and beer.  We had a pretzel appetizer, it was good and so was the cheese, not sure the pretzels where homemade or store bought but they went well with the beers.  For me the best part was the atmosphere.  They had a guy playing the accordion and later a stand-up bass player.  Folks where bringing up birthday and anniversary dedications and the player jumped right in with a celebratory sing-along.  The crowd seemed to know what to do and most participated in the sing-along.  We felt real comfortable and it seemed to be full of a mixed crowd of families from seniors to the kids.  We had fun.

awesome place. came here on saturday for lunch and sat on the outdoor covered porch. you have a view of the river, you are outside but shaded from the sun, what more could you ask for?   i had a few random sides....potato pancake and spaetzle with beer cheese. DH had pork medallions with sauerkraut and mashed potato. all were amazing!!! DH had a beer flight and absolutely loved the maibock. he raved about it all afternoon.   servers were friendly. indoors in the beer hall they had live music of traditional oktoberfest tunes.  highly recommend this place!

If you've never been to Hofbrauhaus, you need to go at least once! It's a good place to start the night if you're planning to hit up South Side. They allow you do stand and dance on the benches to the accordion clad band.  The beer garden outside is nice during the summer if you want to talk with friends and escape the noisy band. The beer is brewed in house... not a big beer fan, but I do like to have one while I'm here.  The mixed drinks were blah. The crowd ranges from 21 to 60's.  Mostly people dressed preppy... read guys wearing pink polos.  For dinner, I was only impressed with 1 time out of 5 times trying it. The schnitzel was the best! German potato salad also was good. The pretzels with beir cheese are overpriced, but good if you're in the mood for that kinda thing. Overall, I'm sure I'll be back, but it's not at the top of my list.

I was here for work, staying right next door at the Hyatt, so on a wintery snowy evening it was the most convenient place to try. First strike against was a bit of chaos in the front, with hopeful diners started to pile up with no greeters. However, once we were seated, the fun began. We had live entertainment with an accordionist deluged with announcing birthday after birthday throughout the evening...apparently this is a popular birthday spot! Nice big place that managed to feel cozy at the same time.  Second strike was by not even 7pm, their most popular pork dish was already sold out! So I had the ribeye instead. It came out medium well instead of medium rare as I ordered it, but it didn't stop me from devouring it. It was delicious as was the food in general (we had the soft pretzel appetizer that hit the spot, too).  I haven't been to a real German Oktoberfest, but with the outfits the servers (all female, it seemed) wore, it was kinda like a Teutonic Hooters!

Always like coming here every change I get when I'm in a town that has one! great beer, if you happen to come in May, their Maibock is killer...and in the fall their Oktoberfest is great. If you can come to one of their keg tapping nights, those are fun. Food is also really good, a bit heavy, but it's delicious. Will keep coming back every time I'm in town!

Hofbrauhaus is a good place to hang out. Apparently, there are several locations throughout the States, but there ain't one in MD, so I had to check it out. A huge restaurant/pub with plenty of seatings and good atmosohere, and they have their own beer brewing machineries, so their beer tastes extra refreshing. Well, for my food, I ordered the pierogies, and it was okay but didn't really impress me. In fact, it was greasy for me. The dish came with pierogies, cabbages, frizzled onions, and sour cream. Like I already said, Hofbrauhaus will be a good place to hang out with your friends and drink some beer with buffalo wings or something but not a place to go if you are craving a delicious meal.

I usually don't go to bigger restaurants but this place was very calm on a Wednesday lunch hour. I ordered sauerkraut balls with a side of sweet honey mustard, which were piping hot, crunchy and yes, super tangy. The lunch buffet for $11.99 was offered numerous times so I went for it. Schnitzel, soup, salad, brats sauerkraut, mash, and rolls and a few other dishes were the selection. First time I went up, hot and fresh. Second time I went up, food was cold thus the four stars. I got a pecan pie ala mode which was thin, smashed and cold and $6.99! The other reason for four stars. I will be back but will avoid the buffet and overrated and overpriced pie.

Some may claim heresy, but I for one am a huge fan of the new Hofbrahaus.  As much as I liked to go and have as many liters of beer and shotski's as my body pleased back in the day, Hofbra became such a party destination recently that the mood had transitioned from a community feeling of fun to a drunk titanic weighting down the South Side.  With the new ID requirements, drink limits, and elimination of a few of the drinking rituals of past, you can actually go to Hofbra on a Friday or Saturday night to relax and have a genuinely good time.  The beer is, as always, historic to the traditional ways of German brewing.  No crazy variations or additions here...  Water, Malt, Hops, and Yeast.  Done.  For those looking for more adventurous craft offerings, you'll likely disappointed.  However, if you have a true appreciation for German offerings, Hofbra is a great asset to the city in that regard.  The food overall is decent.  Nothing to write home about, but the pretzels and beer cheese make a fantastic drinking companion.  Overall, Hofbra continues to be a great destination for locals and out of towners alike (still one of only three or four in the country I believe!).

Pretzels & bier cheese + potato pancakes! Yum. The other things I have tried, including the sauerkraut balls, fried pickles, sample platter of wursts and schnitzel were just okay.  I won't be back anytime soon, mainly because I prefer more intimate dining settings. I came here on a double date and we were yelling across the table because it was so loud. I guess that's part of the experience.

they do a good job with the decor and the ambiance. the food and the beer were hit or miss. I did not try all the beer varieties, but the dunkel is ho-hum. Several of the guests reported the saur kraut, a Geman staple, was not good. Everything also seemed to have an abundance of salt, but that's common for restaurants. It is a good place for birthdays and is generally a fun atmosphere. Parking is not so easy.

We love hofbrauhaus and came for a birthday celebration for my fiancé. We came on a Saturday night during their Oktoberfest. They were extremely busy so we went to the back area with outdoor seating and a second outdoor bar. It was packed! We waited about 15 minutes to finally find a group getting up so we could have their table. Service was a little slow but understandable since it was so busy at the tables. We were extremely upset with the outdoor bar. We waited about 15 minutes to get to the front to order our drinks. Once finally getting seats at the very front, no one helped us for atleast another 15 minutes. We were very disappointed by this, it was a little ridiculous. They were only helping people on the left and right side and completely ignoring the middle of the bar. Food and beer were good. There was a snake in the outdoor area that needed removed by a patron!

It's Like Epcot Center in Pittsburgh, but with Better Food  Yes, this is actually a German beer house here in Pittsburgh at the South Side Works.    The Brau Haus and the neighboring Cheesecake Factory compete for the title of gaudiest architectural monstrosity on the South Side.  It looks like a little beer house plunked down next to the Mon.  When you arrive, you have two choices:  The quiet (read:normal) dining room, and the big beer hall.  We opted for the latter, and were glad we did.  In the big room, your sat next to strangers at big, heavy eight-seater tables.  On one side of the hall, performers in leiderhosen (yes, leiderhosen) play accordions and sing German drinking songs for your enjoyment.  Every so often, the performers call a toast, and everyone in the hall raises a glass and half-sings some German toast song.  It was actually pretty cool, and not that different from Oktoberfest in Munich (or what I remember of it anyway.)  My partner and I split a combination plate ($30), which was more food than either of us could even think of finishing.  It consisted of 2 pork chops, 3 sausages, 3 pork cutlets, mashed potatoes and two kinds of sauerkraut.  The combination plate was a good way to sample some exotic fare without really committing to anything.  We only wished it came with less sauerkraut and more green leafy veggies.  We didn't even come close to finishing the dish, but I still left feeling ten pounds heavier.  There's a reason Germans are so um.... zaftig.  Other (non adventurous) customers near us ordered salads and burgers.  They looked pretty good too, actually.  So you can bring unadventurous/picky eater members of your family to the brau house without fear.    Good luck spelling this place in Web searches.  (Key Words: Brau Haus Hoff BrauHaus)

The location is great by the riverside. Plenty of space is provided in the restaurant, on the patio, and along the river. Live music is ongoing from time to time. Waitresses dress up traditional German costumes, which is very unique. The food is delicious with reasonable price. You must try sausage sampler, pork shank and brewery beer.

It's a great place for a lot of college kids to come on Thursday night. But their food is OK. Their beer is good price with a lot of beer if you are a heavy drinker. Their beer cheese pretzel is decent.

When family or friends come to visit, they often want to come here because of the fun atmosphere and delicious beer. I'm not a huge beer drinker, but I could easily drink a liter of Heffeweisen here. With its smooth finish and perfect hint of banana, I would highly recommend it.  I love starting with the beer cheese and pretzels. I could eat their beer cheese on a absolutely anything. The pretzels are perfectly salty, and the beer cheese is creamy with just a hint of tartness. The fried pickles are also a delicious starter.  For entrées, I love the bauern sandwich. It comes on a pretzel bun and is smothered with beer cheese. The beer cheese chicken is also delectable, as are the schnitzel options and buttered spaetzle.  If you are looking for a loud ambience, sit in the main dining room and experience live music as well as people dancing on the tables. If you are looking for something a bit low key, sit outside in the heated patio area. When the weather is nice, it's fun to experience the beer garden where you seat yourself and enjoy the beautiful view of the river.  If you still have room left, the apple strudel is really delicious. If you're looking for a fun place to try with friends, you won't be disappointed.

Great authentically German-style beers, great nourishing stick to your ribs old-world comfort food and a lunch buffet Mon-Fri  11-2  $12.99(price increases a dollar every year it seems like). Love the outdoor biergarten during warm weather months. Prosit .
This place is a ton of fun.  I loved the huge beers, pretzels and overall lively environment.  I look forward to going again sometime when in Pittsburgh.

Spent the birthday night there! atmosphere is good. Ordered pork shank, sausage and salad. The pork shank is pretty good, remind me of the old days in Munich. Sausage is so so. Will be better if there were band playing on stage.

Awesome beer, great food, amazing location. What's not to like? Just one thing to improve would be the service. Not saying it wasn't good, but the servers could be a little attentive. They seem to wander around without looking at anyone and that makes it harder to flag them down.
I had lunch there today.  The pretzel sandwich was very good.  Very german atmosphere.

I've never had german food before so I have nothing with which to gauge my meal. However I will try to provide an accurate rundown.  We sat in the bier garden outside which has a wonderful view of the river. I'd never been to a bier garden before and it appeared to just be an outdoor area with picnic tables where you eat and drink. Excellent. I am a fan of outdoor dining.  They brew their own beer here and have several options they offer year round such as their premium beer, a light beer and a hefeweizen...they also have a seasonal beer each month.  The beers come in two sizes 1/2 Liter or 1 Liter.  We started off with the fries with bier cheese and bacon, which was so delicious!  For my meal I got the jager schnitzel which was basically a fried porkchop in gravy served with german potato salad and some veggies. After tasting the food here I see why the beers can afford to be so large. Everything was so dense, but I guess that's what german food is.  Overall this is a fun restaurant which seems like a place I would enjoy best just for some heavy appetizers and huge beers with some friends. So if your ever in the Pittsburgh area you should go! You'll have a good time.

Even if you don't like beer, just come here for the atmosphere.  Think of loud drunk people standing on tables singing along to all sorts of random songs.  A great time to be had.  Definitely not the type of place you'd want to eat a good meal though, or so I'm told.

The beer is decent, but I can honestly say you can get higher quality German food at an Autobahn gas station than this dump. How much to want to spend on mashed potatoes?  Do like groups of rowdy bros yelling in your ear? Do you like room temperature sausages? All represented here. This is a frat boys version of Germany.

Had a great experience here! Service was fast, polite, and professional. The facility was very clean. The food was very good, quite authentic actually. The pretzels were really good, pretty darn close to what they have in Munich. The beer cheese was great, as was the tender spatzle. The highlight, to our surprise, were the sauerkraut bites...perfectly fried and stuffed with kraut so well-simmered in pork stock that it tasted like a ham hock, delicious! Really great, give it a shot!
this was my first real german restaurant and i thought it was pretty good. i went with the schnitzel and tried one of the house brews. good stuff!

We went during lunch when there wasn't much fanfare, but our meal came out quickly and was very tasty. I got a vegetarian pasta and a giant pretzel, both were very good and I would absolutely go back.

Fun environment for all ages.   However, if you are taking your family, I would go earlier as I have seen it get a little more adult themed later in the evening.   Beer served up in large glasses, toasts, good food, and dancing on benches. It's hard to go wrong with that list.

Probably the best restaurant and bar in Pittsburgh. There is nothing else like it, everything is authentic German themed and the food as well as their beer is delicious. The atmosphere and live music makes for a fun and entertaining time.

Hofbrauhaus is a phenominal place to go when you have a group of people with you.  The prices are fair for the food which is Bavarian styled.  I sat in the beer hall when I was there.  Service and food were great.  This chain even brews their own beer on site and you can get it either in a liter or 1/2L.  Seasonal offerings are superb, even if some you can only get in 1/2L.

Cheers!  I love coming to the Hofbrauhaus  on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon.  Most especially when it is nice enough to enjoy the outdoor biergarten along with the views of the city and the river.  Maybe it's the German in me, or the beer in me, or the German beer in me?  Eh either way you put it, I'm down with it.  Now I haven't eaten here but on a few occasions.   The food is good enough.  No particular stars or duds that I can recall.  I love German food, but their version is much more Americanized.  It's okay though, since the South Side offers so much in the way of eateries I am happy to just come and spend a couple hours in the sun downing a liter of brew.     Our last visit here was great.    Perfect weather over the Labor Day weekend led to a great afternoon trying their September style Oktoberfest that is brewed in Munich.  I loved it.  Nice seasonal balance of flavors, served in a huge been stein, you just can't go wrong there.  When I do come here I tend to try their seasonal selection first, there are many that are very good.    Sometimes this place can get crazy, and if you aren't into that kind of atmosphere I recommend coming in the afternoons.   I would probably never come here in the evening again, though I have heard they cracked down on their tolerance of bozo drunken idiots.  This is always good to hear.  Bottoms up!

Always have to stop by HB house when I am in the area! I love this place! Great beer selection, awesome outdoor seating, and GREAT FOOD!   My man and I usually share an appetizer and an entree as they have very generous portions. This time around, we ordered the sampler appetizer platter and the sausage sampler plate. Of the items on the sampler appetizer platter, I only really liked the potato pancake and the pretzel with the bier cheese dipping sauce! Be warned, all the appetizers are pretty much deep fried so it was too much friedness for me lol. The sampler came with - 2 pretezels, 2 potato pancakes, 4 deep fried pickle spears, and 4 deep fried sauerkraut balls. It's definitely good to share with 3 or more people.  I enjoyed the sausage sampler entree plate. All the sausages were delish and came with plenty of mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. Yum!  Great place to get your eat and drink on!

This place is awesome! The schnitzel are delicious, pretzels and bier cheese were to die for! The flight of beers was only six dollars and was excellent! The service was decent, not amazing just a bit slow at times. I loved the live music and cannot wait to go back!! Highly recommend!

I went to Hofbrauhaus on a Thursday night... There was a one man German "band" playing throughout the night who was fantastic!  He not only sang German drinking songs but he entertained us with dancing music and even Russian music.  There was a nice little dance floor in front of the stage where my friends and I danced the night away... of course we sat down for the meal.  We had the potato pancakes... which were much better than the potato pancakes at another German restaurant in Pittsburgh called Penn Brewery.  I also got schwinenbraten (excuse my poor spelling).  I substituted the sauerkraut for apple kraut... a very good decision.  And had a pretty good bread dumpling.    I went to Germany last summer and experienced my boyfriends' family's homemade German cooking... so nothing really compares to that.... but the food was pretty good... I'd say about a 3.5 or 4 depending on what you order.  But the experience made the night a 5 for sure!  I also recommend ordering a liter to really make the experience authentic... if you're not a fan of beer (such as me) order a radler.  It's typically half lemonade and half beer.. but this restaurant offers that choice or half sprite, half beer.  It's quite good and allows even the non-beer drinkers the chance to join in the beer song fun!  In conclusion, go to Hofbrauhaus.... go with a group (ideally 4 or more) you'll have a blast if you're not afraid to join in the singing and dancing.

It turns out I didn't need my 1 year of German to enjoy my evening here.   While I've never been to Germany (does a layover in Munich count) or a beer garden, I'm always looking for new places to try out when I'm in Pittsburgh.  My friend promised me that there would be lots of beer and boys, and that was all I needed to go.    We arrived on a Friday evening sometime after 9 and it was jam packed with people of all ages toting mugs of beer that were in some cases larger than their heads.  The only food we snacked on was the pretzels and beer cheese dip, which was really good.  Beer, not sure if it was locally brewed or imported, well it was fine but nothing to write home.  The band seemed to take a lot of breaks, but they were entertaining when they were performing.  Smart space.  I'm glad that restaurants are finally wising up and taking advantage of the terrific river front and opening up spaces for outdoor seating, which can be enjoyed a fair portion of the year.   I hope for the massive size of the place that the owners will find ways to prolong the novelty and that it stays open for a long time.  I agree with other reviews that it's best enjoyed with a large group of friends.  Probably not likely that I would return on a future trip.  I'm not sure if its the women scantily clad in Forever 21 dancing on the long wooden benches or the triple and quad shots of Jaeger served from a ski, but the experience didn't feel very authentic and it's not really my thing.

This place is a German-enthusiast dream come true.  It's a great escape from the typical restaurant scene with fun-loving music and all the lederhosen you can handle.  Situated right along the river on the South Side of Pittsburgh, the place offers a great beer hall indoors, patio seating outside, and a lovely bier garden below - each perfect for any group or family looking to enjoy a fun night out.  It's pretty good eats, if you like German-style food, with some darn good beer to wash it all down.  If you're looking for a "different than the norm" dining experience in a spirited atmosphere with plenty of beer - this is the place.  As the Germans say...Prost!  Enjoy!

Came with a group after 9:30 on a Sunday night (kitchen closes at 9). Since the kitchen was closed, food/drink choices were limited to beer and pub snacks (nachos, chili, and pretzels with various sauces). We ended up getting a round of beers along with all three snacks. The place is definitely very big, which makes it great for groups! I would also say that it was towards the end of the night towards closing so there weren't as many people, although I can only imagine how busy it normally gets during peak afternoon/dinner time. There are a variety of beers that one can get, including the drink specials (one every month), ranging from light to dark beers (stout-like even). Overall, I had a great time eating here. The snacks were all delicious, although I would say that I especially enjoyed the sauce layered on the nachos, which made it quite tempting to pick at again and again. Great place to chill with a group of friends. Will try to come here the next time during normal hours to sample some of their entree/appetizer choices.

Although this is a chain restaurant, which my husband and I try to side step in favor of local spots, I can't say a bad word about the Hoffbrahaus. I'm a consistent fan of the "Radler" which is a customizable shandy, half hefeweizen and half lemonade mixed in house. You can also try a darker version with a dark brew and rootbeer.  I've sampled many of their offerings but I've found my niche with the sauerkraut balls as an appetizer (dip them in the honey mustard - wow!) and the comforting, creamy and delicious Rahm spätzle.  The atmosphere is always lovely and entertaining, great place to drink, eat and sing the night away!
Almost like the one in Munich. Really good food and ok service. Drinking outside by the water is very fun on a warm evening.

If you can't make it to Oktoberfest than the Hofbrauhaus will make you feel as if you are there or bring back memories. Das schnitzel war sehr gut und die hefe weizen war noch besser. The music was non-stop and everyone was having a great . The location is right on the river so you have a choice of sitting in either inside or outside. You can sit outside if you don't want to shout to have a conversation.   The food came quickly, but you can still enjoy some serious pretzels and cheese before your meal arrives. They don't close until 2am so there is plenty of time to pace yourself and enjoy the best beer the world has ever known. So whether a 1/2 liter or a full stein have a good time with some good food with family and friends.

I. Love. Hofbrahaus.   Some of the best German food around - I dont care if its from a world-wide chain - it is DELISH. The bier cheese is amazing, pretzels, schnitzels, potato salad, sausages, sour kraut and of course the beer selection. I love it all. Food is always hot and well seasoned and I have always had good service here - despite the obvious fact that this place can really get crowded and extremely busy. The only reason I am giving 4 of 5 stars is due to it being very overly loud at times if you happen to be there during evening hours (some people like to start the party early, even if you are not sitting in the party hall).

I left Pittsburgh in 2009, and almost every time I come back for a visit, I find myself at Hofbrauhaus. It brings to Pittsburgh that wonderful German experience, from the delicious German sausages to the huge mugs of beer to dancing on the tables. It can be loud and rowdy, but such is the environment of a German beer house, and there are outside tables for those seeking a quieter night.   Hofbrauhaus is located at the South Side neighborhood of Pittsburgh, and the overall area is nice and clean. At the outside tables, you can kick back and enjoy your 1 liter mug while gazing lazily down the river. I would highly recommend, well, everything, but my personal favorite is the liter of Hefe Weizen. One can order the half liter, the 'little beer' as we say, but one should also be aware that such can lead to a night of ridicule and taunts.  Little beer or not, the experience is a must-try, and at the very least, Hofbrauhaus gives you great food and great beer. Have a DD ready, since one can end up drinking quite a lot here. Indeed.

Visited 3/30/14. Had a great time. Service great Place was packed. Food was fantastic. Only disappointment was the band dressed Up in their traditional outfits playing everything But classic German hofbrauhaus music Band played to the College crowd that filled The room. More country western then anything Else. Guess the owners know they will fill The room. Would have been a 5 star except For the music

Good beer, good food, good times!  It's always a fun place to take out of town guests for a night out in the city.  The beer garden is a nice spot to have a drink outside in the warmer months and arrive early if you want a spot by the band to dance on the tables.

This was actually our first stop in Pittsburgh, so I guess I should have reviewed this first! Oops!   My friend tells me that Hofbrauhaus is ALWAYS a staple for him to take his out-of-town visitors. The first things that you'll notice even before you enter the building are the beer silos. Yup, they brew their own beers, which makes it cheap for you and me! The next thing you'll notice are.. the bewbs. The ladies who work here don't wear a complete skimpy outfit like they do at Hooters or Tilted Kilt, etc. but they do show off their top heavy bosoms. Very nice. ;)  We came around 8 and my friend immediately requested that we sat inside when we were asked. Why? Wait till around 9PM and you'll see. Okay, impatient? I'll tell yinz (yes, I did pick up on some of their slang)! Around 9 or maybe 9:30, the Haus Band comes on and plays every type of song under the sun, ranging from The Lion sleeps Tonight to Call Me Maybe. Surprisingly, there was a good bit of country music thrown in the mix. Everything was well received by the audience, who seemed to know every word of every song they played. When you throw together people who know how to have a good time, plus a flow of cheap beer, plus a very good band who knows how to play just about every song you can think of and seems to get better the more they drink, what do you get? Everyone dancing their butts off on top of their benches. It is quite a site to see and an experience you must have in life. My friend did give us a disclaimer that if we wanted to talk about anything that evening, to get it out right away because we won't get an opportunity to later. He was right! Lol.  As if all of that wasn't entertaining enough, there's this REALLY old guy who makes an appearance almost every night. He comes out a little bit after the band does and dances with every pretty lady in the building. Some of his risque moves though.. yeah, he gets away with it because he's an old guy haha. Let me tell ya, he's a hoot and a half! I've got some interesting photos and videos to prove it.  So, aside from the bustling festivities, I thought the food was just okay but the beau and friends all loved what they got. Definitely opt for their in-house brewed beers and pay a little extra to keep a [brand new, never used] souvenir pint glass to take home.  We were stuffed and tired from all the singing and dancing, but my friend took us outside behind the pub and showed us the beer garden, which was very peaceful and romantic (surprisingly). It has a fantastic view of the river and looks even more amazing with the reflection of the city lights bouncing off from it. If you're wanting to grab some authentic German grub, but are not in the mood to burn off all those calories just yet, opt to sit outside.

This may be one of my favorite places of all time haha. Seriously, you couldn't have something like this in southern California, people wouldn't be able to handle it. I'm glad its in pittsburgh.  The yelp description calls this place a pub when its more of a beer compound. Big beers, food, music, long communal tables, and a view of the river.  This is a great place to start off the night with a big group of friends. next time i cruise to pittsburgh I'm definitely stumbling by again.
Service has been getting spotty even when business is slow, food has been slowly going down hill as well. The last time we went and had dinner,we were served instant mashed potatoes(no kidding)

I have really really enjoyed every time I've been here! I've only come for college night, which is Thursdays at 9pm until 11pm with a live band that plays cover songs. I've been here once for dinner, and was very very impressed. Their bier cheese and pretzels are to diiiiiie for and their half rack of baby ribs was amazing!

I had high expectations for the hofbrauhaus after reading good reviews on Yelp, but I wasn't impressed with the sampler appetizers. The pretzels were very ordinary pretzels you can find in the freezer aisle. The "meatloaf" was bologna slices. The biercheese wasn't much more than nacho cheese. The beer was great though.   The atmosphere on a Wednesday night was very quiet and uneventful. But the place looks like it could be really fun during the weekend when there are more people.

Food is ok. Definitely not worth the money we paid. The beer is pretty good. My family is from Germany so I guess I just had high expectations for this place and they were not met. Probably won't make a second trip.

I came here as a suggestion from a local friend. This place didn't disappoint. Service was great, a ton of seating means little to no wait. The environment was great with a feel of a true German beer hall with live music. I had the appetizer sampler and wurstplate, which both were amazing. I ordered a beer sample flight, which complimented the German food very well. My favorite was the kraut, absolutely the most authentic.

The food isn't great. The beer is okay. The atmosphere is a great time, especially in the summer on the patio. It's a "visit once in a while when it's convenient" type of place. Have had great experiences with large groups on the outside patio area. But the beer and food isn't awesome.

I came here last night for a private party.  Because this wasn't the standard setup, there wasn't table service--rather, food was served in a buffet line and drinks were served at the bar.  Most of the available food was fried (not sure if this is the case for the regular menu).  I tried the pretzels with bier cheese, fried sauerkraut balls, fried pickles, and fried chicken nugget things (they probably have an actual name, but I don't know what it is).  The first thing I noticed was how extremely salty all of the food was.  This was particularly true of the pretzels, and the source was the bier cheese, surprisingly.  Indeed, it became so overwhelmingly salty that by my second pretzel, I started using the Gulden's mustard at the table to cut it, which helped tremendously.  Quite frankly, due to this problem, I was disappointed in the pretzels and cheese, which I'd heard was HBH's signature appetizer.  My favorite of the foods that I tried was the sauerkraut balls, which were still salty, but at least had some tanginess due to the vinegar.  The chicken and pickles were pretty nondescript.  There was also apple strudel for dessert, which was okay, but not great.  Not surprisingly, I was thirsty after eating all of the extremely salty food, so I ordered a cherry cosmopolitan to wash it down.  I did really enjoy this drink, which was quite delicious and refreshing after all the salt I'd just ingested.  While I'm aware that most people come to HBH for the beer, I'm not a beer drinker, so I was a bit concerned that only beer would be available for drinks.  However, I was pleasantly surprised by the breadth of the drink menu, which included several cocktails, shots, and wines in addition to the beer.  As others have commented, aside from the beer, the ambiance is what really defines HBH.  There was live music playing most of the time I was there, which consisted of a (strange) mix of traditional German songs and covers of '80's music.  Many of the attendees got into singing the covers and did the whole standing on the bench thing, which was fun.  Because of this, it was quite loud in the beer hall most of the time, but I was able to escape this when I tired of it by going out to the balcony, which has a nice view of the river.  Like Mad Mex, HBH is a theme restaurant that people come to to have a rowdy good time with the help of some liquid libation.  However, also like Mad Mex, the quality of the food leaves something to be desired, so don't go there expecting a great meal.  I'm glad I experienced it once, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return unless a group of my friends wanted to come.

If your looking for German food and entertainment there is no better place!  The menu is all German food, desserts and beer!  The place is HUGE! There is a beer hall and bar where people stand on their seats and sing while eating, there is a beautiful porch and below is an outdoor beer garden with lights, there is also a quiet beer hall.  There is a souvenir room and they have a rent your own stein so that you can come back and have a stein with your name ready for you to drink with!  I ordered the potato pancakes with sour cream and apple sauce, it was good! And I got a Bavarian cream puff!  The servers were all attentive even though they were packed!   A must see!

I have almost never turned down a trip to the Hofbrauhaus.  Check that--I don't think I *ever* have.  I am a confirmed Germanophile, so there's that.  But, what I really like about going there is the atmosphere of gemütlichkeit (geniality, friendliness) that I have experienced myself in Germany.  It's fun sitting at bench seats with a dozen of your friends, drinking from glass steins the size of your forearm, singing "Sweet Caroline" for the seventh time, and I've never had a meal that I didn't like.  Hard to miss on good old fashioned meat and potatoes cooking, although it would be nice to see German style salads, which are completely underrated and amazing.  But, overall, it's a fun place whether you're indoors with the din of commotion or out on the more subdued patio, or the outdoor biergarten next to the river.
Way. Too. Loud.  But the jagerschitzel was on point. Our group left in pain after our meal from the accordion.

Great classic German foods, my dad said that the potato pancakes were comparable to the ones his German grandma used to make many years ago! Very fun on Thursdays when it's college night and they have $6 liters of beer. It's a great place
Great beer, food is amazing. Order the pork shank you will love it. Tried the light lager and it went down so smooth. Great place to have a fun time with friends.

After some time @Church to reflect upon celestial gold... I awaken to my senses that I have not reached the Pitts drink/drive limit. Time for some Hofbrauhaus German Bier Hall Ziggy Zaggy[1].  I check out the line up ziggy zagging out the door.  I went back an hour later. ID check, really?  Guess I don't look drunk enough yet.  I'll do better next time. Everything that I imagine an Oktoberfest Bier Hall.  Great energy, capacity crowd. Loud music lively fun ATMOSPHERE within, airy calmer riverview patio space outside.  Good brews. Hofbräu Munich Weizen. Fun to see the Ski Shots take place. Cannot comment on the Food. Simply an exciting place to be with Friends.  -------------------- [1] That's naturally how I drive by the way
this place rates a bit high on the bro-meter for my liking, but it can be fun with the right group of friends.  3 stars for doing a SHOT-SKI with my friend's mom.

A German beer garden is a German beer garden, huh?  Not if Monday is trivia night.  How fun!   Pierogies were eh, but sausage plate was good.  My date enjoyed beer in thick chilled glass.  Strudel with French vanilla ice cream hit the spot.  The beer hall has authentic German look and bar is very attractive.  Recommend.

Such a great spot to spend time with a big group. The food is amazing! I tried the pretzels, potato pancakes, pork knuckle, and spatzle. The beers are also delicious! I highly recommend this spot--it's a lot of fun!

The Hofbrauhaus is a must stop for anyone visiting Pittsburgh. This German beer hall serves beer by the liter at a reasonable price.  The live entertainment in the beer hall makes any evening here fun with friends.  In my several visits here, I have sampled many items on the menu and haven't been disappointed yet!

After a little more than a week in Ireland with my husband, it was good to get out on a Friday night with the girl posse.  We decided on dinner and a movie and we wanted to try some place we hadn't been to before.  Hofbrauhaus tries to replicate the 400 year old Hofbrauhaus in Munich.  Now since I'm 1/2 German, I thought this place would really appeal to me.  For an appetizer, we started on the pretzels with beer cheese.  I think that they are freshly baked, but they certainly are so delicious.  My main course was the Wursteller, which was Mettwurst, Bierwurst, and Bratwurst.  Piled high with sauerkraut (I love 'kraut.  Why-oh-why do I love stinky foods?), and mashed potatoes, it was so good.  They reportedly have great burgers here too.  No visit to a good German joint would be complete without dessert.  So we split two orders of Appel Strudel with vanilla and raspberry sauce.  I shared one with my friend Marla.  Sherry and Maryann split the other.  Like I always say, "Pump that insulin, Susan, pump!"  One thing, this place can get very busy, so it's best to go early like we did.

The facility is huge! The beer is good! The atmosphere is fun!  While the venue is large and the ambiance was enjoyable, the foodie in me would rate the quality somewhere in the realm of chain restaurants such as TGI Friday's or Applebee's.  If you're in the mood to visit the Southside and you haven't checked this location out, I think it's worth a visit. If you're in the mood for food that is guaranteed not to disappoint, I would keep on scrolling. There are plenty of 4 star worthy restaurants in the Southside sea!

Occasion:  Dinner with colleagues   Atmosphere:  LOUD.  Very authentic I've visited the original in Munich and this place was strikingly similar.  Live music, festive patrons, traditional songs/toasts, etc.  The main difference was that there were separate tables.  Service:  A little slow, but friendly.    Food:  Mediocre, but I don't like German food so not the best judge.  Pretzels and cheese app was excellent.  For dinner I had a salad which was fine and pierogies which were too tough to cut with my fork.  Not good.  Would I return:  Not of my own choosing, but I didn't choose this time either.

This place is bananas. Giant beers? Check. Awesome food? Check. Good location? Check. Second visit, first review. The food is amazing. Schnitzel sandwich, Chicken Sandwich, Steak Salad, Cheese Fries - all hits at our table. Definitely give it a try. Not real expensive either.
Great beer, above average food, fun environment.   Noisy, crowded, not a place I would spend a lot of time at.
Long wait but once you get in it is an experience, the food is great and the beer is as authentic as you can get out of the alps
Food is good but not an amazing selection.  Inside is very noisy, making conversation difficult, but the outdoor seating overlooking the river is spectacular.

There's definitely a solid beer selection here, and the food's not bad either. However, the atmosphere was a little bit off to me.
