Great beer and great food! I've been to the original in Munich and this is nearly as good an experience. On a Saturday night, it fills up quickly with standing room only, so show up early and stay all night. Once the band gets going, people start dancing on the tables and having a great time.

Excellent German food and beer.  Awesome ambience, great for a lively night out.  When the weather is good, the biergarten is about as good as it gets for outside dining & drinking in Pittsburgh.  An all-around awesome place to go.

Tried the beer sampler here and it was good. My wife had one of there pretzels and loved it. I am not a fan of pretzels myself though. Nice atmosphere with huge picnic like tables. I think it would depend on time of day and live band or not if you would want to bring your kids. We were there in the afternoon and it was quite.
Fun! Great place to cut loose with friends that will stand up on benches and sing like their in the shower. Add beer and German food and you have yourself a full evening.
I wish there were a couple more of these places throughout the country. Amazing, genuine German food coupled with some of the best German beer there is.

This place confuses my sense of what is right and wrong.  The food is gross, the beer is gross...and yet the beer is so cheap, and there's soooo much of it.  This place has become notorious for getting people drunk enough that they end up murdering somebody with their car.  But I'm not really sure who is really to blame.  Any other bar if you say, "I'm going to stop by for a couple beers," you'll have a wonderful time.  Here, you will be totally fucked.  Because for real, a whole liter of beer for 9 dollars is a God Damn good value, but nobody should consume anything based on liter amounts.  The crowd varies from massive douchebags from the local colleges or new grads just getting blathered at the bar, to sweet old couples and families who actually love polka music, but everybody seems to be having a good time.  The music is fun.  The service is pretty great, and to be honest, the few times I've been here when it's really crowded, there hasn't been any overly rowdy behavior, so the security presence was probably a good idea.  The food, as I said is really very gross.  And there is a thing called the Hot Brown, which makes me immediately think about what's going to be happening to my body at some point in the future.  Don't call something the 'Hot Brown' unless you're a Doctor trying to explain diarrhea to a child as gently as possible.  Other things are not so bad, and I'll admit that at a certain level of intoxication, I will shamelessly eat a plate of sausages like I'm in an eating contest with the devil.  Points as well for the beer garden in the back.  Go here to get drunk, eat gross things, and listen to an old sweetie play polka cover and traditional songs.  But get a fucking designated driver if you're a Dbag that's just going to end up murdering somebody with your car.

We have been here several times for the atmosphere-which is one-of-a-kind but just recently had dinner here. The german potato salad was excellent! We shared the platter of pork chops, brats, sauerkraut, & potatoes and for 2 people it was more than enough food-we couldn't finish it all! They also have the live german music playing in the main dining hall. After dinner, be sure to go onto the outdoor patio area and take in the great views of the river & city.

I like the Hofbrauhaus a lot.  There aren't that many of them in the world, so we're lucky to have one!  That being said, we only visit once or twice a year, usually in the fall as we're fans of their Oktoberfest brew.  The pretzels are great, and my husband had the Jagerschnitzel which he said was amazing.  I honestly don't know how these people expect you to eat a meal after a half liter of beer and two soft pretzels, so I ordered a side of beer cheese spaetzle for dinner.  It's SO GOOD!    I definitely recommend sitting in the biergarden if it's nice out--you don't have to wait, it's self seating, the service is fast and they have a full bar down there as well.  There are twinkly lights strung up between the trees, plenty of bench seating, and you get a view of the river.  Not to mention you don't have to do the chicken dance down there. :)

the pretzels and beer cheese are a big plus. great beer and if the drunken singing isn't for you theres a great outside patio area. i came here on a friday night and was thrown off by having to wait in a line to get inside but nevertheless, i would go back if i was with a large group.
I get the idea. Meant to feel like Germany. Crowded and bad beer.

One more chain to avoid.  Went here to sample German fare in the beer garden-  great atmosphere by the river-  beer was not as good as I expected and food was bad, even the pretzel tasted like it was served at the ballpark.  I had brats and they were salty and average-  the schnitzel was over cooked- the red cabbage was from a jar. The potato pancakes were greasy- no homefries which I love with schnitzel- and no veal-   Not worth the crowds, the price or the hype.  It reminded me of Disneyland without the rides -big disappointment.

The beer is delicious and each month of the year they feature a different brew. We didn't get a chance to try much of the food there, but the appetizer sampler was really good. It was mostly fried items, but those potato pancakes.... OMG, they were soo good! Wished we had the chance to try some of the other dishes, but we were just filled after the sampler plate. Would definitely come here again since the food looked soo good from the other tables. If you're looking to have fun and plan on having a few drinks in place that provides live music on the weekends, then this is the place of for you
I've always found this place to be a tourist trap.  The service is awful and it's completely overpriced.  This is always a stay away bar for me when visiting the South Side.
I waited over 30 minutes for nachos and they were cold and very unsatisfactory.  The chips were stale and the cheese had hardened. Would not recommend food here.

Went to Hofbrauhaus for lunch as well as late night for drinks. Excellent beer, great service, and unique atmosphere. Outside seating has a pleasant view of the river. The place gets real crowded and loud as the night begins but that is to be expected.   These all sound good until we start talking about food quality. The food was sub-par for its price. If you are looking for authentic German food, you would be disappointed. Nonetheless, I'd recommend getting beer there. If you don't mind crazy crowd, stop by late night to see people singing, stomping on the tables, and getting obnoxious (or you can join the drunks). As for the food? Check out Max's Allegheny Tavern instead.

Don't come here for the food.  It's friggin' German food with cheese sauce galore.  Great beer though.  I don't like anything but the Dunkel, but maybe you'll find one you like.  The rotating selection is nice for a surprise sometimes -- and any place that serves a litre deserves a thumbs up.  Good sausage, potatoes, but the cheese sauce is a bowel wrecker.

Inconsistent at best!   I've had really good experiences here and really bad ones.  Food: it's ok depending on what you get. I've had amazing chicken in the bier cheese chicken but way over cooked when getting the bourbon chicken.   Atmosphere: exactly what you'd expect. A traditional German style beer hall with picnic-style seating and a few booths. Your best bet would be the upstairs balcony...NOT the downstairs gravel lot. I like when they have live ethnic music.  Service: not great, not bad. I feel bad that hey have to wear the cheesy get-ups.   Overall: a little overpriced and touristy, but a definite must-visit when in the burgh, however, if you live here, it's probably not your first choice.   Ps. They have a little gift shop by the entrance/exit...again, a bit overpriced, but you can find some cool stuff.

I know that this place is not "authentic," but I really don't care. As a Florida native, I grew up with chain restaurants and an occasional local Mexican place. German food was not just scarce, but nearly impossible to find in The Sunshine State.  I had been to two other German restaurants in Georgia and North Carolina before trying Hofbrauhaus right after we moved to Pittsburgh a couple years ago. The restaurants were in cliche "German" house-style locations and featured mediocre food only enjoyed by true German food lovers. At the Atlanta location, I turned up my nose to most of the food and remember nibbling on a cold pretzel for most of the evening.  Hofbrauhaus could not be any more different! It has four wonderfully unique sections of the restaurant - formal dining, bier hall, patio, and bier garden. I enjoy the bier hall earlier in the evening before it transforms into a bar, and the patio for late nights and spring/fall weather. Plus, it's covered, so we've even dined out there when it was raining.  The beer is great. My personal favorite is the Hefe Weizen - a delicious wheat beer with a light banana flavor. I also enjoy the Dunkel, their dark lager that hits the spot when the weather is cooler. Each month, they have a different monthly beer, and I look forward to Oktoberfest all year. Make sure to order it early in the month of September in case they run out!  I highly recommend The Works Sampler - pretzels, fried pickles, potato pancakes, and sauerkraut balls, all served with a complementary dip. It's a great appetizer to share with a group of four. Most of the entrees are between $10-15, which I think is very fair for the location and quantity of food. If ordering an appetizer, I would split an entree or sandwich with someone. My husband and I often split the Reuben or Schnitzel Sandwich, which are only $10 and plenty big enough for the two of us. Finally, though you probably won't have room, the Apfel Streudel is fantastic and definitely worth stretching your stomach just a little bit more for.  I would question myself if I was truly in the minority regarding my opinion of this restaurant... but all of our Southern friends and family adore this place. Everyone who comes back for a second visit has requested - even almost begged - to come back here. Several friends and family members have even returned to Florida in search of a similar German place and have been unsuccessful. Maybe it's because we don't have "refined" German palates, but I don't care... This restaurant has made several of us (including myself) who thought we hated German food now become a huge fan. And any restaurant that changes my mind about an entire genre is a gem in my opinion.

I was visiting Pittsburgh early October and came here during a night of drinking. It is very authentic and had a lot of fun here. They had a band in the front playing German songs and everyone was sitting/standing on the benches singing along. I recommend trying the pretzel and beer cheese because it is life changing. I've never had beer cheese so creamy and delicious. Ziggy zaggy ziggy zaggy OYE OYE OYE!

I love this place! The location is good but its impossible to find parking. The food is great but they don't offer mustard without a 2$ upcharge which is just ridiculous. The beer is great but the staff should be trained better on what they're telling the customers. Still, great place to grab some Bavarian food.
I really liked the beer selection at the Hofbrauhaus. The food was decent, however, there was not much of a variety. I would still recommend going here.

I have lived in Pittsburgh all of my life and have only been here once. My boyfriend and I went the other night and it was on Thursday. We only went for a drink and because I have never been there. The service was great and we got a seat at the bar right away. Little did we know, it was $3.00 beer night at 9 o'clock. Once we sat down for a minute and relaxed, we saw the band and I got excited. I have heard you can dance on the tables with your beer and have a great time. Once I looked up, I saw a rush of people coming in (mostly college students). It was a lot of fun and great atmosphere, just really crowded.  Since it got so busy we only got the pretzel appetizer with their beer cheese. Neither of us typically like beer cheese but we liked theirs! It was really good. We will definitely be back to try more food.  It is a great place for groups of people. I would recommend a table with a group of people rather than the bar on a night like that. Overall, it was great!

Went here during Octoberfest with a bunch of close friends where we all had a blast. Best part was everyone was on top of their bench singing along with the band! Traditional beer garden with excellent seating both outdoor and indoor.

We came here the other weekend with a fairly large group of friends (including a few of their small kids). I have been to the Hofbrauhaus in Cincinnati and done the crazy dude bro drink-and-stand-on-the-tables-all-night experience....for this outing, however, my friends and I came here on a tame Sunday evening for dinner.  Despite it being a Sunday, the atmosphere was still fairly festive, with a loud accordion player gleefully playing German tunes through the hall. Luckily, our big group was seated a bit off to the side out of the main dining room by the bar, so we were still able to hear ourselves talk and think. This was my first time being in the Pittsburgh location, and it looks like it would be really beautiful in the summer -- they have a gorgeous outdoor space that overlooks the river. Unfortunately it was February, so all I could do was look longingly at the patio and wish for warmer days.  So as I mentioned, I came with a fairly large group of friends, which included 3 toddlers. I'm not sure if this made our table undesirable or whatever, but the service was pretty abysmal. Our waitress took forever to take our orders, rarely came over to refill our drinks, and just in general pretty much ignored us the entire time. I don't know if she was just a terrible waitress or if she thought maybe the effort-reward ratio was not favorable enough to put up with such a large group. But either way, it was highly annoying to everyone and soured our experience.  As for the food, it was pretty pricey and was on par with the quality you'd find at, say, an Applebee's. Very run of the mill. I got the Dunkel Bourbon chicken sandwich with a potato pancake in place of the fries. The sandwich was unremarkable -- the chicken breast was oddly shaped (way too thick and too short), so it didn't fill the bun at all. The bourbon sauce didn't have much dimension to it -- it was mostly sweet, with only the slightest hint of tang from the bourbon. Although the sandwich was a bust, I did enjoy the potato pancake -- it was crispy without being greasy and had a delicious onion-flavored potato filling. My friends also felt pretty ambivalent about their meals -- the reuben, the schnitzel sandwich -- every item my group ordered was met with a "mehh." Not terrible but not great (especially for the price).  So my takeaway from this experience is that this is not a place to target if all you're in the market for is a good dinner. Perhaps their wheelhouse is beer and merriment, but food and service definitely ain't it.

The food is great, the music is great, the beer is great, the staff is great and the atmosphere is great....I really like it here if you can't tell! Hofbrauhaus is always a fun time if you're looking for tasty food and entertainment. Heads up-Thursday night is college night and it's usually very busy when school is in session

There is now happy hour, with specials on appetizers and the standard beers! Yay! Also wanted to mention that the lunch buffet is excellent, with a great salad bar, 2 soup options, several wursts (with curry sauce available!), schnitzel, mashed potatoes, German potato salad, fried cabbage, and a rotating meat entree available for ablut $13.
Mmmm......pretzels and.bier cheese [said in a Homer Simpson voice].  And of course the beer and environment are incredible.  Sitting outside on the river celebrating the start of Oktoberfest.

Pretzels And Bier Cheese is a must. College Night on thursday is also the best deal around. The band almost never stops playing and people are up and on their seats by 9:30. The bench seating makes it a great place for big groups, and the outside seating by the river is great in the summer and late afternoons.

This place just makes me want to go to Germany! I love beer and I gotta say the wide selection of beers is great. It's so nice to have so much to choose from. The food is also really good. I think all the items I have tried have been great

Fantastic food, decent draft beer! My girlfriends and I were there on a Friday for the live band (dressed in lederhosen!). We had a blast dancing on our benches and they even sang the song we requested. Good service and hospitality. Awesome experience all around. Would highly recommend, especially if you're german!

Good beer and food. However, most of the time when I order a liter of beer it has lots of head (foam) and by the time it subsides I get a third of a liter of beer. I can see a 1 - 1 1/2 inch head but 2-3 inches is not acceptable. Paying $10.50 for a beer and I get a third!

If you love german food you will love this place. I seem to only go when I can sit outside in the beer garden due to the overwhelming noise inside. The service is a bit slow outside also... so why a 4 star then? The beer is great and the atmosphere is fun. Go knowing that you better get pretzels as soon as they seat you because food will be a long wait. You will enjoy yourself more.

I was in town visiting some friends and they brought me to the Hofbrauhaus. It was alot of fun. It's a traditional German beer hall with the long tables, the 1 liter beer mugs, and wait staff in traditional German costume. The beer was of course great German beer made by Hofbrau and the food was excellent. I ordered a bratwurst dinner that came with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. I thought the prices were reasonable and the service was good. We ordered pretzels for an appetizer that were perfect. The place can get loud but its expected in a German beer hall.

Super packed on weekend nights. Great beer with lots of choices!... If you can get to the bar.  There was a very long line for the bar tonight so we each only had two drinks within about 2 hours.  Didn't eat here, only went for drinks but the food looked like standard pub food. Exciting atmosphere, even a live band tonight!
Great drink selections. Creative delivery of the drinks. Service was fast and attentive! Food was delicious every time.

I still don't get the fascination with Hofbräuhaus. Working close by has led to countless happy hours there, and living close by has led to meeting friends there quite a bit...which means I've been there a lot, but rarely because it was my destination of choice.  First, the beer is good and plentiful. Heck, depending on the monthly brew, the beer is sometimes REALLY good, and the food is decent. I've never eaten an actual meal at Hofbräuhaus, but I've tried almost all of their apps since I'm typically there for happy hour, and they're all pretty good. Fried pickles, fried sauerkraut balls, soft pretzels with beer cheese...I mean, what's there to complain about? The perfect app menu for beer-accompaniment.  Unfortunately, Hofbräuhaus loses me with the atmosphere. I'm fully aware that it's the atmosphere that is supposed to be the draw, and based on the crowds they get, it's working. Perhaps I've outgrown the old get-drunk-then-stand-on-a-table-and-toast-in-a-language-that-I-don't-really-know stage of my life, but I often find the main room of Hofbräuhaus to be loud and obnoxious as opposed to celebratory. Granted, I prefer being able to hear the people I'm talking to, and I don't need a random Tuesday in the Spring to feel like Octoberfest, but based on the number of people that go to Hofbräuhaus, I'm clearly in the minority.  The safe bet for a good time at Hofbräuhaus for those of us looking for a more relaxed experience that takes advantage of the positives of Hofbräuhaus while skipping the annoying, is this: get a small group of friends and hit the outside beer garden when the weather is nice. There are few things more relaxing than partaking in a delicious liter of beer in the beer garden...next to the river...on a sunny day. If the weather isn't cooperating, another option is to get there early before the craziness starts in the evenings, but regardless of how happy the tunes from the accordion might sound, the drab environment just never does it for me.

Our first time here. I ordered sauerbraten.  It was excellent. If you are used to German food, it was very good, not near "sour" enough for me however. Atmosphere is traditional German family style with loud music and friendly atmosphere. Service however was horrible. Saw our waitress only twice in a two hour period. Everyone's glass was empty and needed refills. Everyone enjoyed their food however. We will likely be back and hope for better service next time around.

I admit that I've been putting off a trip to Hofbrauhaus for a long time. It wasn't that I was against going there, per say, but my absolute hatred of the South Side Works and what is offered there--both establishments and personalities--made me think I would loath it just because of its location. But my affinity for beer, especially beer in giant glass mugs, and the fact that it was the location of one of my good friends 25th birthday party celebration finally brought me in.  I arrived sometime around 11 on a Friday night to a line circling around the side of the building. At once I thought my fears were confirmed, a long line of what I perceived to be South Side douche bags. But as I got closer I realized that it wasn't just a bunch of frat boys in line, but there were people of all ages and all walks of life waiting to get in. On top of that the line moved very quickly and all in all only spent about five minutes waiting to get inside.  Once inside I made my way to the bar area, which was much more spacious than I thought it would be. That being said, Hofbrauhaus was still extremely crowded leaving little room to stand without bumping in to someone or having someone bump in to you. The dense crowd also left long waits for beer. The bartending staff tried their best to keep up, but there is only so much they can do when you have hundreds of people making human sardines around the bar all trying to order a beer at the same time.  I ordered a liter of Dunkel, and when it was finally served to me, tasted pretty good. I'm not all that familiar with German style beers so I'm in no position to comment on its quality, but from an amateur perspective I thought it possessed a strong and unique flavor. The price for a liter wasn't bad, especially considering the location of Hofbrauhaus. I believe the "big mug" ran somewhere between $7 and $8. I wish I would have had more time to try a few of the other brews but I didn't get the chance.  The atmosphere of Hofbrauhaus is a bit more rowdy than I expected. Long rows of thick wooden tables and benches line the open space between the bar and the stage which aren't used for sitting but instead standing upon. From this perch one feels like he or she is the life of the party singing songs and swinging mugs about, beer sloshing out like a geyser.  The band was lively, fun, dressed in authentic Bavarian dress, and I could tell they really did have a passion for the music they were playing, but I was really hoping for something a big more authentic. Most of the songs they played were American covers, nothing but a few songs were German.  My experience at Hofbrauhaus was a lot better than I originally thought it would be. It wasn't as much of a corporate juggernaut bar like many of the other bars in the South Side Works area, even though the amount of people they allow to be packed in at once makes you wonder if they care more about their profits or the experiences of their patrons. Will I come back? Probably yes, but only from time to time. I much prefer smaller less crowded and noisy bars, but if I have to pick a larger venue bar Hofbrauhaus would be the place.

this is a great place to go to on a Friday and Saturday night. They have music, Dancing, and they have a great way to bring people together. The beer is great and the food is really good, if you enjoy german food of course. The servings are well worth it. I am not sure that this would be a great place for first date, but it is a great place to go with a group of friends and celebrate an occasion. They have out door seating during the warmer months. The ambiance is nice and open. over all a thumbs up.

Went here to celebrate birthday party for my brother- beer great unfortunately kids night.  We got here at 7pm, did not receive our food until 920, food was a free for all- they had no clue what people ordered and all of the food came out at different times, im finished with my meal now, ordered a steak medium it came cooked more than well done- i finished 15 minutes ago unfortunately my grandfather is still waiting for his dinner.  I couldnt even finish my dinner because it was so bad so im outside smoking a cigarette while the rest of family is waiting on their food- some have been done for past hour.  Pretty pissed at this place for ruining my brothers birthday especially with the whole family here.  If i wasnt enjoying the beer it would have definately scored a 0 or a 1.  We have money to pay for meals so i dont really care if our meal is comped, im just upset that we will not be able to spend another family dinner here.

Came here for some brews after dinner! This place is a lot of fun! Hey have live music with a great German band and it's a very casual and fun environment. They serve the traditional German haufbrau beers hat came in either the .5 or 1L beer steins. I always go with the original lager. This haifbrau house in particular is a lot more lively and more fun than others

Hofbrauhaus is definitely a novelty restaurant and not somewhere I would frequent.   The environment is interesting where they take on the full atmosphere of an old German beer hall. I don't even know what those would be like but I imagine that it's most similarly like this. The women were clad in scantily short skirts and dresses that really highlighted their boobs. I don't think anyone could have been safe from those...  Anyway, the food. My friends got the Dunkel Bourbon Chicken and Schnitzel sandwich while I got the garden burger. First of all, it was hard enough trying to find something on the menu when everything was unpronounceable. The food itself was okay, the garden burger wasn't my taste because it seemed like they tried to put a mexican-style spin on it while still trying to keep the german flair. My friends seemed to enjoy the Schnitzel and Bourbon Chicken but the mashed potatoes were nothing special and she left the entire thing on her plate.   Overall, I would definitely take someone here purely for their aesthetics but probably wouldn't come here anytime otherwise.

Tons of fun, great live music, food almost authentic. Sausages and schnitzels were great. Beer disappointing out of the better flavors and were waiting for days to tap new beer, friday and Saturday nights Rock.

If possible, I would want to divide this review into three separate portions: the food, the beer, and the atmosphere due to the fact each of these components would get a different rating from me. To sum up the food: 1.5 stars. I've tried several of their more traditional German items (Jagerschnitzel, sauerbraten, sauerkraut balls, and bratwursts) in addition to a few of their sandwiches (the Dunkel chicken sandwich and the pretzel sandwich) and have been very underwhelmed each time. It's always too salty, too greasy, and flavorless. I've tried some of the apps as well (sauerkraut balls and pretzels) and the pretzels, while they taste like those giant super pretzels you'll find in the freezer section of the grocer, are the only thing I will now order when here and only if I absolute need something to munch on with my beverage. The biercheese, again is overly salty, and was served practically ice cold on this last visit. We just used the regular old spicy Heinz mustard for dipping instead.   The beer, in addition to the atmosphere of the biergarten, is really the only reason why I personally come here. I would rate the beer at 3 stars. Out of their standard fare beers, I enjoy the Hefeweizen the most. I love the hint of  banana flavor and wheat beers are my second favorite (after IPAs of course!), and I highly recommend this option if you enjoy a wheat. It is perfect on a hot spring or summer day! They always have a "beer of the month" too, which happened to be a Maibock this month. I'm not really into the darker beers, and since that is mostly what is available here, I can't really comment on the darker ones myself, however my friends that enjoy darker beers rave about them, particularly the dunkel.   The atmosphere, particularly the outside Biergarten, is my favorite element of Hofbrauhaus. "I don't like to sit outside on a beautiful day and enjoy a cold beverage"-said no one ever! Or at least I hope no one ever......Anyways, it's beautiful near the river where you can watch the boats go by or people making use of the riverfront trail. You can also exit the biergarten right onto the riverwalk where the docks are located. Some of the tables have umbrellas which provided some much needed shade this past Sunday when it was 90 degrees outside! There are servers for the tables or you can enjoy watching a game at the bar, which is also a shaded refuge.   Just a note about my most recent visit this past Sunday afternoon. I went to use the restroom in the Biergarten and there was a female server literally having a melt down, screaming and swearing up a storm on her phone (to her mother since it was impossible to NOT hear her end of the "conversation" and I'm sure her mother really appreciated this on Mother's Day) about having to work out in the Biergarten and how she wasn't going to make any money because it was a Sunday, and she just "couldn't do this anymore". While it's not like this really bothered me,I just thought-obviously-it was extremely unprofessional to behave in that manner, particularly in the bathroom where paying customers could hear and see her. In this day of technology, I'm sure her whole cuss-word filled rant could have been communicated via text messaging. Just saying.   So in summary, come for the atmosphere, enjoy a beer or two, and I'd advise skipping the food in favor of one of the many other options in the South Side.

I sincerely wanted to like this place.  I have been there 4 or 5 times, always with the same result: exceptionally below average.   The ambience is cute, with the waiters in Lederhosen and the waitresses in drindles, and a seemingly-authentic menu.  The beer is above average, but barely.   Now to the food.  Without the beer, I would give zero stars.  Absolutely horrendous.  The few standouts were the fried cabbage and weisswurst.   The weiner schnitzel was well below average.  The kraut was cold and bland.  "imported" or not.  The pork cutlets were so incredibly dry that even gravy couldn't save them.  Cute try at a German bierhall, but the food is awful.  If you are looking for authentic German fare without the Lederhosen and tacky decorations, go to Max's Allegheny Tavern on the North Side.  They have been doing it well since 1903, when the area was called "Deutschtown" because of the large number of German immigrants.

3.5 experience. First dinner in Pittsburgh! Also, my first time trying German food!   Party of 4, reservation at 7 pm. TBH, it was pretty empty when we came...but I hear it gets hella packed later at night and on weekends!   Parking: street or parking structure a block away. The area is still under renovation, so please pardon the dust.   Menu: extensive and the font is hard to read (LOL). Separated into:  appetizers, soups, salads, side dishes, burgers & sandwiches, HB specialties, Wurstl, Schnitzel, and Haus favorite.   TLDR;  Service: 4/5- Ladies were super nice and gave us ample time to order. But, they did forget us halfway through the meal...  Ambiance: 4/5- indoor has a country band playing on stage, and a really nice bar with huge beer tanks. Outdoor seating that overlooks the river. They even have games on the bottom floor! The area is a new shopping center, so you should walk around after your meal if it isn't too dark or chilly! There is also a running trail behind the restaurant.   Quality of food: 3/5- maybe this isn't my type of food, but for what it's worth, I would only categorize this as "American traditional".   Pricing: 3.5/5- pretty reasonable for the quantity you get! Alcohol is also decently priced.   We finally ordered:   SOUPS 1. 2 Kartoffelsuppe (creamy potato soup) // YUM! Isn't this just like clam chowder without the clams? 2. 1 gulaschuppe (beef stew with tomato/paprika base) // YUM! Maybe because I was on the plane all day, but this settled my tummy.  SPECIALTIES 1. Scheweinebraten (slow cooked pork roast) // Oh wow, big portion! I actually really like the pork. Kind of reminds me of pork loin though? Potato dumpling was not bad...why are people obsessed with this?  2. Sauerbraten (marinated beef) // Oh boy...too much red wine sauce. The beef was also too dry...but the sides were good!  3. Dunkel bourbon salmon (pan seared Atlantic salmon fillet) // Yum! Fresh. Also came with some steamed vegetables.   WURSTL 1. Wurstplate (bierwurst, bratwurst, frankfurter) // I'm not into sausages...my friend ordered this and finished it clean though!  HAUS FAVORITE 1. Half rack of baby back ribs // YUMMM. I haven't had good ribs in forever!!! I like. Better than other places I've had in CA!   Overall, interesting dining experience. I wouldn't mind coming here for some big portion, comfort food! However, quality does sacrifice. Everything is hella rich in flavor...maybe too much.

I went here for a work gathering after an all day meeting in Pittsburgh. We went here because one of our colleagues is the accordion player in the band.It has a reputation of bring a fun place with lots of German beer. I enjoyed the food and wine as well. The German  music was pretty authentic as the band (including my colleague Mike Grk) played anything the audience requested that was a German song.  The band even has some groupees. In all, a fun place to have dinner and drinks in good old Pittsburgh.

Really good German style food and great beer.  But the atmosphere is what really makes this place great.  The beer garden is one of the best places in Pittsburgh on a nice summer evening.  The inside can be loud and raucous, especially on the weekends.  If you're looking for a good time, this is the place.

Great beer (especially their Dunkel , a dark lager), good Oompah band for music, good service.  The sauerkraut and ham ball appetizers, the fried pickles, soft pretzels and potato pancakes were delicious.  The wait was 75 minutes so we didn't stay for dinner.  If you want camaraderie singing along to Sweet Caroline while drinking a good brew than this is the place for you.

Good beer. Good pretzels with bier cheese. Good environment. All in all, a good place for some German grub and drinks.   On the other hand, this place definitely attracts the rowdier crowd. With it's long, shared tables, raucous clientele, and live music on the weekends it's not an environment for the faint of heart.
Drinks are good and food is good as well. It's a lot of heavy food. But the atmosphere is great and the servers are friendly

Went there because I've been wanting to try it for a bit now. They had a sign up that said to seat ourselves, which we did. However, we were completely ignored for a solid ten minutes before getting service. I had the sampler platter. All great food, def would recommend. I also had the litre of the hefe weizen which was an incredible beer. There was a special event on patio which seemed to have all the workers attention.
First time going and it was great!  Food was incredible and atmosphere too!  Can't wait to go back!

I've been here quite a few times in the past, but today was the first time I ever came for the lunch buffet (I had a coupon for $2 off).  The buffet was all you can eat, and included a nice salad bar, and a small selection of German foods, such as schnitzel, spätzle, three kinds of meats including brats, a wurst, (and I forget the name of the other one), cabbage, sauerkraut, German potato salad, mashed potatoes, two kinds of soups, and rolls with butter.  The only thing missing, in my opinion, were potato pancakes (kartoffelpuffer).   The beer was not included in the buffet, and today I had the August brew, "Sommer Weizen" (5.6 % Alc. by Volume, which is a darker, maltier version of the Weizen bier with hints of banana and clove).  I enjoyed the buffet, but would probably prefer to order an entree off of the menu next time.  Today was the first time I sat outside on the veranda, and it was pleasant sitting outside, watching the river and people go by on the nearby river trail.  Nice place for lunch, but no live music today, I guess that is only for when the bier hall is full of people.  Prost!

Hofbrauhaus is always a fun place to go, whether you're inside or out. I've never gotten a full meal, just appetizers and beer. The beer is good, I wish they had a bigger selection though. The appetizers are on the small size and seem commercialized, which gives me the impression that's how their food would be.

Pittsburgh is lucky to have a Hofbrauhaus. I wish we had this establishment in Jersey. It just made every beer garden I know a boring joke. This place is legit--complete with staff members with outfits, live accordion music, and well, of course, German food and lots and lotsa beer. It's such a fun place. The food's pretty good and affordable and so as the drinks. I'm totally a fan.

Maybe during Oktoberfest you'd get the "Disney" like experience others talked about (which would also be lame), but, on the night we came it was just lame.  Walked into some old guy playing keyboard version of Journey's "Don't stop believing" and a few young dudes standing on tables, swaying back and forth singing along.  The whole of Pittsburgh doesn't have enough polka outfits to pay each to play one night of the week?   I had German friends complain at how ridiculous Hofbrauhaus in Munich was, but if they saw this, I think they'd want to shoot themselves.  Also, I found the original in Munich not so bad- decent prices, decent food, and mostly full of older german couples or men!  Maybe during Oktoberfest it's awful, but I liked it.   This was just pathetic- the "german dishes" were quite frankly terrible.  I forget which sausage my husband ordered, but he said it tasted just like breakfast links.  I ordered the kasespaetzle, a dish I ate a lot of and liked in Germany.  The two versions can't even be compared.  This one was full of nearly raw onions and tasted like it was covered in alfredo sauce, and was pretty much one big lump of doughy noodle.  The only reason it's getting 2 stars is because the beer was good (though not being a beer connoisseur I can't really compare to the original).  I was a little peeved when I wanted to order a radler (my other favorite in Munich, along with the mushroom and potato dumplings which were absent from the menu here) and my 20something should be at TGI Fridays waitress gave me a blank look.   I didn't go here for fun or spectacle, and that is where I went wrong.  Maybe it'd be more up my alley if I ordered a "shot-ski" and burned off my tastebuds.

Great spot on the Mon!  Excellent beer and food. We are regulars here and service has consistently been very good. Check out the steinmaster club and get your own locker. Pork Porterhouse and Schnitzels are the way to go!

What do Munich, Las Vegas, and Pittsburgh have in common? They're each home to the authentic Hofbrauhaus German bier garden.  I was pretty excited to hear about the recent opening of the Hofbrauhaus in the ever expanding Southside Works development.  This place is absolutely massive.  I'm not exagerating when I say that they can probably fit 1000 people between the two indoor dining rooms and the two huge patios.  The long wooden benches in the main dining hall are simply designed for mass, communal consumption of beer.  And really, that's what you want to do here.  Hofbrau beer is served in half liter and full liter glass steins, and it is good.  My favorite is the hefewiesen (wheat beer).  It's one of the best hefeweisens I've ever had.  I also tried the seasonal Maibock on my most recent visit.  It had nice body, but at over 7% alcohol by volume, you're not going to finish too many liters of this before you hit the floor.  The Dunkel (literally, dark beer) was also good.  I don't know if they serve it in the main dining hall, but I'm hoping that they serve beer in the 2 liter glass "boots" that they sell in the gift shop.  Back in the day, when I used to live in Madison, WI, there was a German beer hall called the Essen Haus that used to serve beer in these two liter beauties.  There was a game we played with the boot where everyone at the table would take a drink and then pass it to the next person.  If you passed it on, and the next person finished the boot, you had to buy the next boot.  From what I can recall, it was a good time...  As for the food, well, it's German...  If you like wienerschnitzel, bratwurst, and sauerbraten, then you'll be in heaven.  Personally, I find German food heavy and bland, but that's just me.  The pretzels and beer cheese were a great appetizer.  Perfect beer food.  One of my dining companions ordered the "Hot Brown" (Turkey and swiss cheese over a potato pancake, covered in beer cheese and, oh, yeah, bacon).  It was really good, but dense.  In summary, go here with a large group of beer lovers and drink yourself silly on good (reasonably priced - $7/liter) German beer.  Fire down a few pretzels to soak up the alcohol.  Das ist gut.

I'm a beer loving girl.  Ever since I was a child I would steal a sip of my dad's frosty mug when he wasn't looking.  Now that I'm an adult and of legal drinking age, visiting Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh I'm allowed to have a liter of beer,  or as I call it "beer as big as your face,  without the lecture.   With an accordion player dressed in lederhosen and women with corsets pushing up their assets, you feel like you've been transported on a European vacation.  German comfort food is on the menu with a little American flair. It's a destination spot - obviously I bring my Dad every time he visits Pittsburgh to make up for all of those stolen beers over the years.  Typically the only food I order are Bavarian pretzels and bier cheese.  The food isn't the best, but the beer makes me nostalgic.    If you're looking to get the full experience,  stop by on the first Wednesday of the month - its keg tapping day!  New beer is unveiled,  a parade of men and women playing instruments and waving flags while bringing out the first new keg of the month.  If you arrive early enough (say 6pm) you can get a table and stand in line for a free first taste of the beer.  That tower of mugs will be filled with a frothy brew and I'll have a big smile on my face.  If you're looking for something off the beaten path and feel a bit parched,  fill your mug up with some bier at Hofbrauhaus.  PROST!

Awesome Sauerbraten. Simply put this is a great place with great food. Good beer and wonderful staff. This is my second time here and if I lived in Pittsburgh I'd be a regular. It's worth driving 50 miles for. The strudel is straight from Germany and worth saving room for. Get the vanilla bean ice cream and you'll be happy.  If your only here for a day, eat here. Unless you just flew in from Germany.

If you want beer and bro time, this is the place to go. Headed here for a colleagues going away party and that's all you see from one end of the patio to another. Not my idea of fun, but it could be yours! If that's what you're looking for- give it a shot!

Better beer to be had.  Hofbrauhaus is still pretty new and I admit the noisy part of the place is a lot of fun.  I found the beers to be only so-so.  Get the pretzels with beer chesse.  They're really good.  This is the kind of place you go very infrequently with a large group.  One time I was there we were seated next to people who really were not into the vibe.  A real killjoy but a risk you take in a beer hall type of place.  Prices were reasonable.  Can be very crowded.

Walking into this place took me back to Germany, where I was stationed for three years. Very authentic, very Duetches, the girls wearing traditional dresses and bier by the litre or the halb. Und der vas a man playing polka, albeit I was spared lederhosen.      Started out with the German potato soup, fantastich. Very filling and flavorful, great beginning on this awfully cold nacht. Had a bit of my friends pretzel and bier kasse, very nicely done, as well.      Moved on to the entree, Baurn schnitzel. Delicious! Took me back to the jaegerhaus we used to frequent in Lampertheim, it was well prepared with succulent cheese and ham and a fine potato cake. This was accompanied by a very nice dunkelweissen, rich but not overbearing. My only disappoint with the meal was my yearning for a doppelbach, but they didn't have any.      The only reason they get 4 stars instead of 5 was the one man oompah band played 'Don't Stop Believing'. Sigh.

This place was really great - not that they had anything to do with it, we also got to see a double rainbow - my first!  We were within walking distance from this location, so I'm not 100% sure of available parking, but it's a huge place with lots of indoor and outdoor seating.  Food selection was large, pricing was very good and the servers were all very nice.  The gift shop isn't too overly priced - picked up a cool Germany hat for 20 bucks and it's a cool hat to boot!
Hofbrauhaus is fun to go to but it gets packed and is a bit too much after awhile. The Radler which is a mix of beer and lemonade is delicious though.
Its really good! The fries are on point. Got the pork shank. Meat was fall of the bone. Can't wait to come again and try something new!

Great edition  of a Bavarian restaurant. This is my second visit. First time I sat outside and the views were amazing. I enjoyed the pretzels, the beer and the sausage plate sampler. First time I came in late with my husband and it was after work. The kitchen was still open but it was the end of their shift.he was a weekday and the crowds were limited. I loved it  The second visit was on a Friday night and it was great again. We initially thought we wanted to sit   outside but it was rainy and humid. The restaurant was very crowded inside but they had live German music with an accordion. There were even people dancing.We decided to sit at the bar and the service was exceptional. I love this restaurant because of the environment, because I love beer in because their menu is authentic German

Wish I would have come here at nighttime, as I hear people dance on the long wooden tables! That's my only regret! At least the accordian player was still doing his thing during our meal. Totally German place with authentic German food and great BEER in huge glasses.  I also regret not buying one of those glasses. Unfortunately I wasn't that hungry when I came here, so I just got a side of Spaetzle, and it was delicious. My boyfriend got the potato pancakes, and they were also very good. SO AWESOME HERE. If I'm in Pittsburgh again, I'd love to go back at nighttime when the place apparently comes more alive.
Love this place! Great all year round, even better in summer with beer garden and outdoor concert venue next door. Beer brewed here on site. Great German style food too!

I have always thoroughly enjoyed every evening/night spent here. I love beer and find it hard to complain about a place that makes my love so much more enjoyable. The skis, samplers, food - great establishment. It's huge but tends to get packed especially on the weekends and obviously during the summer. The beer garden is great though. Everyone comes to have a good time and I've never actually seen anyone trying to start something. I once came for a networking event and that was fun too. All in all, never lets us down!
Great atmosphere!!!!  If you love to sing along this is the place for you.  Food is great but if you are eating healthy this will be the one place to come on you cheat day!!
Had a great time, good food, and great beer! Went on a Thursday and sat in the main hall. Service was a bit slow, but understandable because of how packed it was. Overall, awesome!

Had a friend's birthday party here in a small, semi-private area and the service was great. As a non-drinker, can't comment on the beer, but the food was very good. Pretzels and bier cheese was a great starter and the Bavarian schnitzel, fried cabbage, and spaetzel was great.

If you like German food and beer you'd like this place. It wasn't my cup of tea but it was run well enough and the wait times were good. I'll say that there aren't many vegan options but I wasn't expecting there to be since they specialize in sausages. The chairs were extremely impractical and uncomfortable though.

Happiness = (Meat + Beer + Carbs)^2  Was looking forward to this place prior to moving to Pgh this past summer.  The first time I visited this beer garden was when I visited the original one while on a beer garden crawl in Munich.  Beer was great.  Meat was great.  Truly memorable experience in Germany.  Now that I've been in Pgh since summer of 2013, this Pgh branch has not disappointed me at all.     Food (8.0/10) = Seems like not many people like the food here.  I personally love what I've ordered.  1. Bavarian Jagerschnitzel = flattened pork smothered in mushroom, bacon, and gravy.  2. Oktoberfest Schweinshaxe = big fat ass pork shank with crispy crackly skin.  ?Beer? = duh.  Hofbräu Hefe Weizen and the Hofbräu Dunkel.  1 L.  No BS with these beers.  Ambiance (9.5/10) = The beer garden is very close to the river.  I havent been in Pgh long, but I don't know any other place with outdoor seating along the river.  The garden is the best.  Has a "community" feel to it.  Haven't spent much time inside yet since weather has been good, but looks like a party is going on every time I walk thru.  Service (8.0/10) = Good service.  I get my beer and food.  That's important.  Overall Opinion = Haven't been disappointed by this joint at all.  The best asset of this place, other than the beer, is the beer garden.  If looking for outdoor dining/drinking in a very casual chill environment, check out Hofbrauhaus Beer Garden level.

Love this place! It was my first time trying it out and the atmosphere was so unique! Loved the German music and attire -- gives it a real authentic feel. Plus, the food was DELISH! Definitely recommend.

First time here.  Great location w/ river views. Great decor. Large portions.  Had the liter Hefewiesen.  The bier cheese and prezels are a delicious appetizer. Had the Käsespätzle, delicious...along w/ the Black Forest cake for desert.  Recommended, looking forward to visiting again.

Mediocre pork chops and food in general, but what it lacks in the culinary department it makes up for with FUN! You are guaranteed to a "dancing -on-the-table" kind of night on the weekends with live music, but my favorite is sitting outside on a rare not-so-humid summer night.

The experience of walking into this river-front homage to a traditional German bier hall feels less like my idea of Oktoberfest in Munich and more like Bill Murray's life a la Groundhog Day.  I can say this because I've been there 3-4 times and the story always plays out the same way...it's up to you to somehow drive the plot in a different direction.  Perhaps I'm missing the point...after all we return to most establishments seeking a consistent and memorable investment of our time and money...but I like to think we as Pittsburghers take more pride in our small locally owned watering holes than the same hoopla you'd find at Busch Gardens.    There is no formal parking lot at the Hofbrauhaus, just several nearby multi-level parking garages and a handful of metered spots in and around the Southside Works complex.  Chances are you'll pay something to park within walking distance.    Once inside everything seems larger than life...the tall ceilings, medieval sized tables that seat dozens, the shameless display of cleavage, and most of all...my disdain for boring and flavorless lagers.  I'll admit...I am a total beer snob...always hunting down the hoppiest of imperial IPA, but I will gladly find comfort in a nice malty dopplebock if it's available.  Alas, i've learned from the Seasonal release schedule that February is the only time of year when the style is on tap.   The food is exactly what you'd hope for; variations of wursts, schnitzels, potato pancakes and pretzels as well as some "American" choices - Burgers, Salads, etc.  It's the cavalade of starch and sausage that you'd want while eating cafeteria style to the tune of Journey's "Don't stop believing" honked out on accordion.    Who doesn't like to have their meal-time conversation interrupted by yinzers of all ages shouting a mispronounced "ZICKE ZACKE"  atop the same wooden benches that make it near impossible to "shimmy" yourself out to use the restroom.    Though I've never taken part in a shot-ski...I get the appeal.  The overall sense of merriment at the Hofbrau is perfect for getting large groups together as an impersonal celebration of special events, birthdays and a place to party with absolute strangers on any given weeknight.  For my money, I'll stick to Penn Brewery to get my fix of German fare with house-made brews...but thats just me; The hop-head whose personal nightmare is accepting being just a predictable part of the crowd.
Very good food but seating is limited during weekenda when the band is going. I highly recommend the lunch buffet during the week!

How did I miss this place. It's is much like Munich and is a close as you can get to an Octoberfest celebration this side of the pond. Good German food and good service. Last night they had open seating which was fun for us and we got a chance to share a table with some folks who were a blast. We ate and a German band was setting up in traditional garb. They had two accordions in the band and I figured we were in for an evening of traditional German beer hall music - I was way wrong. These old guys were doing cover songs! Great sing along songs which were great. If you just want to sit and eat quietly don't sit in the main hall. In a few minutes everyone was standing on their chairs singing and dancing. It was a blast. Oh and the beer - great German variety and it was excellent.

I've only been to Hofbrauhaus a handful of times, but I have had a good time on all occasions. Whenever I've dropped in, strangely enough, it's almost always been midday on a week day ...  Anyway, I am a huge wheat beer lover to I of course go with the Hefeweizen, which is quite tasty (though I still prefer Paulaner's over all others). I like all of the windows that let in an ample amount of sunshine, if the sun happens to not be behind a rain cloud (that happened to me on one visit; it poured. Thank God I was inside chugging beer). It was always empty on my visit except for one when I went later on in the evening. Then it was filled with college students who gave the place a slightly party-ish kind of atmosphere, and I don't mean that in a bad way.  As far as the food, I can't speak to it as absolutely nothing on the menu appeals to me. I've had their pretzels once and those are really good, but I'm not going to drive all of the way to South Side Works for some damn pretzels lol. I haven't heard many good things about their food. From what I gather most people just show up for the beer, especially during Oktoberfest.  I highly suggest visiting when their tapping the kegs for Oktoberfest. THAT was a fun time. ;)

This place was great and is super large inside as well as outside. We sat on the Terrace which has a covering in case for rain. The garden area as closed while we were there due to weather.  We tried the appetizer sampler and the Bavarian Sampler for 2 to split with 4 people. Both dishes were plenty of food. Appetizers  - Fried Pickles - I still haven't found one that I like. Sauerkraut Balls - they look like mini hush puppies with cabbage and ham inside.  Potato Pancake - texture is nothing like a pancake but looks like a fritter. Tasty. Pretzels - nothing special Sampler - Smoked pork chop is SALTY. Bleh! Sausages are delicious - though Hot Dog consistency. Schweinsbraten or roast pork - nothing special though I must say it was the healthiest of what was on the plate Strudel - Not sure if this is authentic but the strudel lacked any crisp to it and it was soggy and sad. I would not order this again. Beer - Buying 1 liter of Beer to get a glass is crap - almost twice as expensive as just getting the beer alone.

Location Location Location.  90% of what makes Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh a lovely place to visit is it's positioning where the river meets the Southside Works. Noon, afternoon or evening, there isn't much that beats the atmosphere inside or outside of any Hoffbrauhaus but this location in particular has lovely view's of Pittsburgh and a stunning river-view terrace.  Everything is pricey but you're paying for the novelty of a traditional Bavarian style atmosphere. I mean hell, the waitresses wear costumes. SO that aside, the food is actually pleasantly tasty schnitzel and even not schnitzel. THe pretzels are a perfect snack, beer cheese on point and last but obviously not least the beer is just dandy. Little size is $5 and Big is $10. But big is a liter and is basically 3 drinks...two of those and you will find yourself dancing on the table(which is both acceptable and expected) to the house band playing various covers and favorites.   Go late for late night shenanigans or early for a hearty meal.  This place is just a good time. GO!

We finished having our drinks and were about to leave, when all of a sudden this security guy stops us and asks for our id. Note that we had entered with showing our id and were buying drinks by showing Id for two hours. It was very insulting to be treated like this -- being stopped in full public view and questioned. Whatever your rules are, that was clear discrimination.   Horrible experience.

What a great place!  Stayed in Pittsburgh for the weekend and ate there twice. Service was good and very helpful. The food was great and the beer was even better.  It was too hot to eat outside by the river, but inside was awesome. The atmosphere was very lively with plenty of music and singing.  I would definitely go back next time I'm in town.
Great food, beer, and environment. Pressers We're amazing but too salty. Fortunately the salt could be dusted off. Same for the beer cheese dip

Whoa... What a treat! The beers here are very good. I love the Gignormous liter glass steins the beers come in. I feel so powerful and manly when I drink out of those... That is, until my arm and wrist starts hurting from fatigue...  Service is great. They are prompt and I've never had to wait to get another round of orders placed.   The food is good. Very hearty and well prepared. My favorite is their pretzels. It's just the right amount of crunch on the outside with a slight sprinkle of salt and has a chewy, warm, fluffy but yet delightfully doughy inside. My goodness... I can eat a big one by myself and still want more. Try it with the dips, the cheese dip is my favorite.

I tend to prefer the more "authentic" places in the grittier part of Southside, but for what this is - an ersatz German beer hall - it's very well done, from the decor (which is on the fancier/nicer side of beer halls I've been in), to the beer (which is basic but good, again sticking to the German beer hall motif), to the food (again, think beer hall classics), and to the staff/atmosphere.   Speaking of the staff, they were friendly and helpful without being intrusive (thanks Kate!), although you might find the traditional costumes a bit much, especially in an era of heightened sensibilities. As for the atmosphere, I found the band very helpful to the overall vibe, but as others have pointed out, if you're looking for a quiet dinner/beverage, this probably isn't the best place for you - you'll definitely get much more out of this place if you're willing to buy-in and join in.

It might just be the almost-summer, almost perfect weather. but the patio at the Hofbrauhaus was a perfect place to spend an afternoon with two beers and two plates of good food. My love of German food is well-documented here, and we made good choices in the Weisswurst platter and the pretzel sandwich with ham and beir cheese -  both were uncomplicated and delicious.  I might have liked it a little less if I sat inside where the music was louder and the atmosphere generally kitschier, but on a summer afternoon, the patio suited me just fine - I'm looking forward to a return visit.

Heavy rain did not deter people from celebrating Oktoberfest at Hofbrau in October 2009 as we ended up waiting on the line for a quoted time of 45 minutes before we can get seated in the beer hall at 6pm on a Saturday night. We were hungry and we were thirsty so we tried to make our way to the bar while we waited. Although the bar was fairly large, It was so packed we had to try and cut our way through 3 rows of people before we could even make it to the counter. We decided against it and pestered the hostess again if there was any available seating anywhere. It was also just another excuse to talk to the beautiful ladies welcoming people at the door.  They were immediately able to accommodate us at the separately enclosed quiet room and we took it. That service receives a check mark in my book for now.  There was of course a good selection of beer on the menu priced decently for light and dark beer connoisseurs alike. As for the food, I could've done better with my $14 then get the Weiner schnitzel here which ended up just being a fried pork cutlet with some sides. It tasted just like any standard fried pork cutlet and could be gotten for just $6 at Rose Tea Cafe in Squirrel Hill. I even ordered it with an egg on top (extra $1 charge with meal) and they forgot to put it on. So they decided to charge me $3 for one cooked egg to put on top of my pork cutlet by myself. (I rectified the situation when the bill came) Although the food was pretty standard and nothing to write home about or in this case, to yelp, one nice thing I liked about my meal was the German potato salad side. Of all the sides my friends and I ordered, we believed that that was the best side.  I'm sure the meal would've tasted a lot better if I had a couple more beers in me and we were swigging away in the beer hall but since we ate this sober, I was able to give my taste buds a full chance to try out Hofbrau's quality and a 3 out of 5 star rating of its food.   If I were to come back next time, we would probably just be in the bier hall for its beer at night. We weren't able to experience it, but it looked like everyone was having fun in there.
Love this place!   The food is good.  The atmosphere is Great!   Love the Craft Beer.  The music is interesting & different.

Hofbrauhaus' German-Beer Hall inspired restaurant/pub provides an alternative dining and drinking experience in Pittsburgh. The atmosphere at Hofbrauhaus makes the visiting this establishment worthwhile. There is an eclectic group of people all indulging in heavily encouraged drinking while listening to upbeat traditional folk music. There are also skis for drinking beer; if that means something to you then Hofbrauhaus has it; if that sounds like nonsense then go to Hofbrauhaus to see what I mean.  If you are willing to participate in the high energy cheering and singing, then you'll definitely enjoy an evening here.  When I came here we ordered a few samplers, pretzels, and bratwurst to share. I have no standard to compare the authenticity to, but the quality was surely acceptable.  As for beer, Hofbrauhaus brews its own beer on site. You can order a sample of the house beers and go from there. Also, I've read that Hofbrauhaus serves Cask Ales, but I cannot confirm this from memory.

I was visiting my friend in Pittsburgh and she recommended going to this place. Upon arrival, I fell in love with the seating arrangement, the music and the atmosphere. Our server was incredibly nice and when he realized I'm a vegetarian he brought me a "vegetarian menu!" How thoughtful!! I also noticed that they have a gluten-sensitive menu. This just makes ordering food a whole lot easier and I truly appreciate their effort to accommodate! Our food was delicious and our server was more than nice and checked up on us a couple of times. Definitely recommended!

On our way to Baltimore, my coworker wanted to stop for lunch around the Pittsburg area so we decided on this place after the first pick was closed.  I'm not exactly sure where this is located in relation to Pittsburgh but the location was really nice. Looks like all new development.  Since I've never been to anything German before, this was an experience. Although it might not be "authentic" it was pretty cool. The waitresses are dressed up in their attire and the tables are all wood. Gave me a Harry Potter feel.   Since we stopped by during lunch, we opted for their lunch buffet. I must say, unless you want something really specific off their menu, the buffet is the way to go! A few different types of sausages, a full salad bar with soup, and the usual comfort German foods. I loved their spicy sausage. Everything was great but I like that kind of food. Carbs and sausage! I saw that there is a location in Ohio too but it's 2hrs from me. I wish I could've got a beer but since I was driving and it was a company vehicle, I had to be responsible.  On our way back, I was tempted to stop here again but it would've been dinner time.

We came to the Hofbrau House as soon as it opened on a Friday for a special promotion luncheon for work. We ended up parking a couple blocks away in a parking garage which was fine, but I would have been happier if the valet was all day and not just for the dinner hours. We were greeted and met our party near the back of the restaurant. The seating is just like you would find at an authentic Oktoberfest in Germany, long community tables. I was so excited to try the food and hoped it would taste like the food did when we lived in Bavaria. Of course we started off with some Hefe Weizen, goes down like silk. Smooth and sweet just like I remember it. We also ordered the Pretzel and Bier cheese app and the Works Combo appetizers for the tables. Loved the sauerkraut balls and the potato pancakes with the apple sauce were fantastic! That works platter would also be good as an entrée, a little bit of everything. I went with the original schnitzel for my entrée. A huge piece of lightly breaded pork, still tender and juicy on the inside with cabbage, buttered spazetzle(substituted this for the potato salad) and a side of cranberries. I had never though of having cranberries with pork, but it was an amazing accompaniment. Loved it! It was also a very large serving with plenty of leftovers to take home. My husband had the Hot Brown. No bread in this as it had the potato pancakes for the base, tons of turkey, gravy tomato and bacon. This was the perfect sized lunch meal. During our meal there was also a man playing an accordion so we had some live German music. Definitely want to come back here again. Great food, great beer.

My favorite place in Pittsburgh.  Great food and great beer that are consistent no matter what night you go.  On weekends they have a live band that comes in and plays crowd favorites and people get on the table benches to dance. If you want a louder experience eat in the main beer hall, for a quieter one go to the dinning area. In the summer it's best to eat in the outdoors beer garden next to the river.
I love this place on weekends. The ambiance is great. Food is ok ok, but the beer is great.

I love this place! I enjoy the food, the beer, and the atmosphere immensely. What I don't enjoy? The service. The service is usually incredibly friendly but takes forever.  And seriously, any place where getting up on the tables and dancing is encouraged, for both men and women, that is definitely the place for me!
Came here for a quick drink and snack so we got a half liter of Hefe Weizen and the bier cheese fries. The food and drink were great! Service was pretty slow and hard to get the waiter's attention.

My family and I were looking for a fun place to go for our last night out before I went to college, and we decided on the Hofbrauhaus.  It was a great decision.  We got the Giant Pretzel and sausage platter for a starter.  Both were delicious.  The sauerkraut that came with the sausage was soooo good.  I made sure I got a side of kraut with my meal because of it.  The Pretzel was great too, and the sauces were phenomenal.  For my meal I got the pork.  The one i ordered was the Bavarian Jaugersniztwel.  It had mushrooms and bacon on top, and the sauce with it was absolutely great.  The sides were also good.  The waiter told me before that the veggies were frozen and not good, but I ordered them anyways, and I really enjoyed them.  The workers messed up my mothers sides, but they fixed it with no problems at all, and within sixty seconds, we had the new sides.  We even got to keep the wrong sides, which I was very happy to devour.    Everybody at the table liked their meals, and we even had enough room to throw down some apple strudel and chocolate cake.  They were both delicious.  I would defiantly recommend this place.  The atmosphere is beyond fun, and if I am excited for two birthdays from now when I get to spend my 21st Bday cheers-ing German beers and singing along with the rest of the place.

Only a handful of these German themed restaurant/ bars in the entire world and one of them is in Pittsburgh. Go here on a Saturday or Friday night and forget about it, BUT THAT'S HALF THE CHARM! You need to be in the mood to be elbows to elbows, standing on tables, singing, screaming and doing shot skis as a group. The food is good as well. Very German. But I recommend going here for a fun night out with the guys or gals.

This place is always fun on the weekends. I always get their hefeweizen full liter. There's usually entertainment inside and during the summer they have a great outdoor area. I was lucky enough to do a shot ski before they got rid of them and it was quite the experience.

Soo I definitely wasn't expecting the whole Oktoberfest feel when I went in there. This is the first thing I did when entering Pittsburgh.  There was live music and the whole place was buzzing. I loved every second of it and the food was great. The Hefeweizen might have been the best I have ever had and the Bier Cheese served with soft pretzels was fantastic!! Highly recommend to anyone who wants some authentic German cuisine or is looking for a fun atmosphere with their meal.

Hofbraughhaus is a one-of-a-kind experience. During our visit, it was a blast to drink beer out of a liter mug, try different German sausage, sing along with our fellow dining mates, and just enjoy the atmosphere!   The beer served was very tasty, not really heavy, and we really did enjoy the sausage plate. If you're in Pittsburgh and looking for a unique experience, check out Hofbraughhaus!

Meh. The atmosphere was really nice - we sat outside and had a nice view of the river, but the food was mediocre, expensive and inauthentic.   We didn't try the beer but it's probably alright and would have enhanced the experience. Although no prices on the drink menu is never a good sign!

I'm a big fan of the Hofbrauhaus in Munich, so of course I'd love a stateside version! This is true to the Munich original, if a bit smaller in scale. Same good German beer, same good German food. If that's what you're looking for, you're in luck! If not ... I'd strongly suggest you go elsewhere.  Beer: They have the traditonal lager, a hefeweizen, and a dunkel. Each month they have a special beer of the month, and they also seem to have a 5th brewer's selection at most times. Beers come in 1/2 or full liters. That's it!  Food: My family is German, so I do love a solid German meal. I was in town on business, so I definitely took advantage of the situation to stop in. We don't have too many great German spots in my hometown, so I have to get my fill while in Pennsylvania. I had a pretzel followed by a sandwich, and I subbed in a potato dumpling for a side. Yum yum yum!  Atmosphere: Standard beerhall fare. I was there a bit early (6-730ish), so the main hall was relatively empty. There was a German musician on stage, and overall it made for a pleasant dining atmosphere. Since the crowd was pretty sparse (it was also really cold while I was there), I also had great and attentive service. I'm sure that during College Night or on the weekends, though, the place can get crowded! Perhaps not as much as elsewhere in Pittsburgh as the location seems to be pretty touristy, but I'm sure that's a draw for many.

We were first standing in line at the Cheesecake Factory. It was a 45 minute wait and we were trying to catch a movie.  So I Yelped what was close by and this place popped up.  I wait listed it.  We were there in 5 minutes. There were lots of people waiting and I walked up to the podium to check in. They told the person in front of me the wait was 30 minutes.  I gave my name and they sat us immediately. Love that feature!!!  My 16 year old had the roast beef Au jus.  She thought it was tasty. She said she would order it again. I had the bratwurst of the month which was a smokey bacon flavor.  Came with sauerkraut and fries. I enjoyed it along with their own brewed beer.  I like Blue Moon and Shock Top and they gave me one of their brews that tasted similar. We were in and out and able to get to our movie on time.

I was really excited to try this place since I love German food and drink. Okay, they serve beer by the liter, that is awesome! They have a full German menu, also awesome! The reason for three stars is that the service was pretty much "meh." I think our waitress quit judging by the reaction of our second waitress. The food was alright, nothing amazing, but acceptable nonetheless. I am not sure if it was an off night or if I built it up in my mind to be something it wasn't. Either way, it was an experience, but once was enough.
Best German potato salad Lovely atmosphere Great servers Beer  Bier cheese great Would come back

I had never been to Hofbrauhaus before, and my German food experience is somewhat limited. I'm also not much of a beer drinker (more of a wine girl). However, I really enjoyed eating at Hofbrauhaus with my coworkers at a conference. The atmosphere feels like a giant biergarten (or at least what I've seen in photos) and is very festive. There's a guy doing live accordion music at dinner that makes things feel more authentic as well. The service was a bit sparse (understandable given the immense size of the place), but friendly.   The food itself was delicious! The one letdown was the beer cheese pretzels. Everyone I talked to RAVED about them, but I found them to be incredibly salty to the point where I didn't really enjoy them, and literally scraped off all the salt from the pretzels. The cheese itself was ok. Seemed like standard bar fare. However, my schnitzel plate was fantastic! Perfectly cripsy, great cabbage sides, and really hit the spot. Overall, fun experience and I would definitely come back!

So good, I had to come back two times in the weekend I was here.  Why I knew I would love this place: two sizes for beers... 1/2 Liter and full Liter. The beer brewed is very good and I can tell they serve it with pride.  Came the first night quite late for some drinking / pretzel eating, and most of all.. standing on the benches signing along with the polka band, making new friends and having a drunken good ol' time.  i wish they would have more of these establishments, as it was high positive energy the entire night! The songs were all very sing-a-long-able... especially the song about Alice!  Next day I came back for an actual meal. The latkas were absolutely amazing, and I had the wurst sampler. All three were extremely good, and I am not sure which one I would choose if i had to choose one. Paired with the mashed potatoes and gravy, it was a match made in heaven. The patio was open the day we went, so we got to enjoy the views of the river as well.   Great meal, great beer, great times! I will definitely be back!

I can't help but feel like someone brought me to German Disneyland. The outfits (Dirndl) for the waitresses make me feel sad and embarrassed (but...also impressed by their cleavage). How come the bros get by in just a white and blue button up? Well, at least the dude playing the "accordion" (it was a piano) was in legit lederhosen. Work it, German Santa. He played some folk-ish music including Edelweiss. I drank their Doppelbock. It was tasty. It was 8.0% but I could REALLY taste the alcohol more than with other Doppelbocks I've had. I like that they have the ABV on there and also describe the beer. Apparently you can choose your beer sizes. That's fun.  We only got a pretzel with bier cheese, a sweet mustard and obazda for $9.50. Too expensive for a hunk of bread. Should be something like $6.   I could see the appeal of this place for Oktoberfest but I think I'll stay away until then. There's better beer to be had that doesn't subject their female waitstaff to dress like beer wenches.

Hofbrauhaus is such a fun concept and is situated in an amazing location right on the water. Walking in, you're overcome by the cute outfits that the staff is wearing, the authentic decor and homey feeling. This location is big and perfect for large groups I like the biergarten concept outside. All of the beers that I have tried have been great. Service is generally pretty good--not over the top fantastic, but no complaints. Avoid the food. It is GROSS. I've tried 4 different items and hated all of them. I guess Germany isn't known for their food, so why should this place be any different? They do not have a happy hour (at least in the beer garden), so don't expect any deals on their pricey pints.

I have been to the Hofbrauhaus in Columbus as well and they are no different. That's a good thing! Affordable food, good beer, loud music, and noisy people! Not a great place for a quiet dinner, but if you are looking to have a fun time and a few beers with friends, go there and let loose!

There are two very important things one needs when dining at Hofbrauhaus: 1) stretchy pants and 2) a designated driver.  The stretchy pants are for comfort after you have gorged yourself on sausages, pork, sauerkraut or any number of German delicacies.  The designated driver is for when you've drunken yourself into a stupor after one gigantic beer.  I've only been there a few times, but each time, I have a decent experience, great food and awesome beer.
