Yes, I know I'm breaking my rule about corporate food, but there aren't that many locations (it's not like it's a Chili's - on every corner) so I don't count it as being too, too corporate.  I forgive because the food is actually pretty good.  My one warning is that if you're looking for a nice, quiet intimate place to dine, go elsewhere.  If it's busy, you might be seated at a table with strangers (there are booths, but not too many).  On top of that, Hofbrauhaus is loud even on its slowest afternoons and absolutely nuts on a Saturday nght.

Ich spreche Deutsch .... but I hate German food.  I do love me some Hofbrauhaus though.  GOOD cheap beer and authentic German food served up with accordion music?  The festival atmosphere is awesome.  Highly recommended.

The Beer is okay,  not a bad deal for 7 bucs.  The atmosphere is very loud if your inside.  plenty of seating outside, but it does get crowded late, and they don't let  you stand around.  They have a huge area outside with picnic tables, but beware they have a limited menu if you decide to eat there.    The food is alright, nothing to write home about.  In my humble opinion Penn Brewery is (was) more authentic.  and I'd rather spend money there.  This place is good for a large group ready to party and drunk enough to not care about the food.  The best thing I've had here was the sauerkraut balls.  I went here like 4 or 5 times, and I've had my fun there.  Like I said its good for a party.  Get the Shot Ski.

I go out of my way for German restaurants/bierhalls and I can say for sure that Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh is in my top 3 in the country.  I've been coming back to this place over the last decade and I can tell you that it's been solidly consistent in terms of quality too.  If you like German style beers, you can't go wrong with any of the options that they have on their menu.  From their traditional styles of year-round offerings (Munich Helles, Munich Dunkel, Hefeweizen) to the monthly rotating options, you'll never have a bad beer here. They have one or two rotating options that are on the hoppier side, but if you're the type of jagoff who refuses to drink anything other than IPAs/DIPAs/imperials, just go somewhere else.  Or consider the beers for their historical context and appreciate a different style that's well-executed.  There are few things more satisfying than the taste and heft of a 1 liter stein full of good quality German lager.    The food has always been fantastic here as well.  We always, as in 100% of the time, get the pretzels and bier cheese.  They are fantastic and are the perfect salty complement to your first liter of beer.  Everything that comes with The Works Sampler is also really good and it's good for sharing if you have 3 or 4 people. For my meal, I typically get the Wurstplatte and I've never been disappointed.  My only complaint about it is that I would rather that it come with a Weisswurst rather than the Frankfurter.  The Frankfurter is good, but I'd prefer the more traditional Bavarian white sausage. We've also had the Hot Brown and a couple of the schnitzels before as well and we've been satisfied with everything. I also recommend getting the Spatzle as a side.  I'd go with the buttered option, but the bier cheese Spatzle is also good, if a little on the heavy side.  I agree with some of the other reviews that talk about going on an off-night or earlier in the day if you are going on a weekend.  The wait can be pretty long Thursday nights-Saturday nights and it gets loud with the live bands.  If you're looking for a fun night out with friends, it's not a problem, but if you're looking for a quiet romantic dinner date, go earlier on the weekends or on a week night.

Run far away. Then run some more. We celebrated a friend's birthday here, and the entire thing was actually new to my experience: the dance hall, the three-tiered outside seating area, the hoochies, the brosephs, the smoking, the fighting, how we got stared at for being gay. Won't be back. I actually have adopted use of 'Hofbrauhaus' as an adjective to mean 'way out of control and unpleasant' -- as in, "Oh, the law school halloween party was completely Hofbrauhaus."

They had an amazing crispy pork shank dish that came with a tasty potato side and very well made sauerkraut. I love pretzels while drinking beer, so that was an amazing plus with the bier cheese dipping sauce. The "German" beer was pretty standard. It was nothing to coo over. Our waitress was sweet, but it was obvious that she was overwhelmed because she alone was waiting on about 1/3 of the outdoor seating area. This is a fun place to go drink with the pals, especially if you have a larger group to accomodate. Prost!

This place was awesome! I was visiting my boyfriends family in Pittsburgh and trying to think of places to go during the day when he suggested we go here and sit outside and have a beer. We had a great time! We went on a saturday afternoon and it was a great place to go on a gorgeous day. The beer was delicious and so much fun to drink a whole liter from a humongous glass. We did not do much eating, but am definitely looking forward to coming back here!

My wife and I (along with our one year old daughter) had a wonderful family meal there while sitting in the outside area facing the "Mon" river. We arrived at about 5 PM and were seated without waiting and had a high chair waiting for us at the table. It was a perfect place to take our child because it is loud, even outside.  My wife and I each started with a beer (The Hef and Pils) and were pleasantly surprised by the taste. We sampled the three different dipping sauces for the soft pretzels and found them all to be very delicious. Finally, we split a wedge salad and the dunked chicken sandwich. Both meals were prepared well and served promptly. All of the service was perfect and the pacing of the meal was slightly slower than you might expect for a chain restaurant, which we both appreciated.   I would recommend this restaurant for families and would say that on top of being family friendly it is also wallet friendly.  Cheers!

We went here 3 days in a row, they had a keg tapping on Thursday night.  What a great place, man it was awesome.  I've been to the Munchen and Vegas one and as soon as I realized there was one here we were like, "3 nights straight we're coming here!"

I continue to be a devotee of Hofbrahaus despite not being a beer-drinker.   Who cares about mead when such items as the titanically flavorful vessel of breaded, fried pork called the Schnitzel Sandwich are on the bill of fare? The lettuce, tomato, red onion, pickles and bier cheese only compliment the flap of crisp, succulent pork held tightly within a Kaiser roll, making the foreign familiar and universal. The yinzer in me I had half a mind to ask for slaw and frites on top. Instead, the fabulous, dead-perfect Belgian-style tuber sticks came as a side.  I thought I tasted lard, which is always a good thing when devouring deep-fried foods.   The ultimate potato pancakes can also be had at Hofbrahaus. As thick as hamburger patties, they crackle like kettle chips on the outside, yet are plush, muggy, and starchy like au gratin spuds on the inside. So tasty were they, that I almost ignored the sour cream and applesauce that accompanied these precious, oily, crispy, shareable starters.   One must also consider the carnally creamy, benevolently bacon-laden comfort food tour-de-force that is the Hofbrauhaus Hot Brown...or Turkey Devonshire. No matter. You, the reader, the eater of good food, deserve such pleasures in an increasingly maddening world.   And dessert...praise Thor for dessert!  This time it would be the black monolith known as The Chocolate Stout Cake that would terrify my taste buds. Imbibed with yeasty, beastly, beery essences, the wedge of decadent darkness consisted of a frighteningly fudgy, dense body and an airy chocolate mousse frosting straight from Niflheim.  Is it touristy, ktschy, Epcot-ish? I am not concerned. The food makes its own statement, and that statement comes down bold like Mjolnir smiting mountains.   P.S. The service was terrific overall, and considering the restaurant had just opened for the day, we almost had it all to ourselves for most of our early lunch.  P.P.S. As Kay, her parents, and I gorged ourselves on the Teutonic delicacies, a gentleman in olden Germanic attire serenaded us with his accordion. Unfortunately, he knew no Blind Guardian songs.  P.S. The Hot Brown and the Chocolate Stout cake were specials and are not listed on the website's menu.
Great place to have beer and food!!! I really enjoyed myself especially with the live entertainment.

Wonderful food & great service. Not sure if reservations are possible, but try to call ahead. Fun atmosphere and delicious good if you are a fan of German cuisine, which I am. Was looking forward to some cucumber salad or bloodwurst but alas it is not in the menu. Oh - great beer too! Will make this a regular stop when in PA in the future!!

This review is solely on the food.  I like the schnitzel a lot - it hits the spot every time!  I also enjoyed the schweinshaxe, but it's a bit pricey.  I'm wondering what it would take to get them to serve real German pretzels, the huge ones.  The sausages are just ok.

This place is fantastic!  It's like walking into a palace...awesome beers, great food, extremely friendly service, great music.  You must have an appetizer when you go...try the pretzel, it comes with several awesome sauces for dipping, or the nachos or anyting there.  Their steaks are fantastic, sandwiches, dinners are to die for.  The beer that they serve is fantastic as well...even if you don't drink, you should start if you go there!  LOL  Definitely one of my favorites....

Pretty good German ambiance, especially the music. The music made me feel like I was at the eatery next to the "It's a Small World" ride at Walt Disney World, which I loved.   Plus, the food was flavorful, and there was plenty of it.   Hubby and I both had the bourbon glaze... He had the burger, and I had the chicken breast. Both were juicy and tender.   I know... German restaurant and neither of us had brats. But hey, the fried cabbage was yummy.   We'll probably bring our out-of-town relatives in next time they visit, as there's shopping nearby and a great view of the Mong.

Fantastic beer, large area, boisterous crowd.  The service is decent for how incredibly crowded this place gets.  Can't comment on the food as we drank the whole night. The place gets crazy later at night, everyone was dancing on the tables. Gotta love the live music.

I must say that this place was very enjoyable... We came here around noon on a Monday to find the place pretty empty, but I have a lot of German heritage, so I am having sausage and beers!  I got two sausages with a soft pretzel (off the lunch menu, see photo) and they were AMAZING! Even the mustard that came on the side was good, and I hate that crap most of the time! I also ordered the Hofbrau Hofbräu Dunkel beer (see photo), a 5.5 by volume. It had a nice full flavor, not to heavy and because it was made there it makes it just a little extra special...  We also had a pork sandwich on the table, a potato pancake, and a veggie burger... The fries are worth mentioning as well... VERY good!  I would love to come here on a weekend to sing and drink with a big crowd, but that didn't happen this go around. If I was ever in the area again, I will defiantly come back!

Ich liebe Hofbräuhaus! Seriously, I love this place. I love the beer, the food, the atmosphere, and most importantly, servers in dirndls. Even if you think you won't like German food, give it a chance. It's incredible. Prost!

Fun place.  Had the jagerschnitzel.  Nice sized portion, rich mushroom sauce.  Fried cabbage and German potato salad on the side.  All very nice.  The buildings main room is done up like a trad German beer hall.  Nice big bar.

Got here late and had a 32 oz of the dunkel. Good German style beer. The bartenders only let you buy one at a time which is lame. The live band plays Ein Prosit about every 25 minutes but stupidly ends it with the Australian cheer.  We stood on the benches of the tables, had soft pretzels with beer cheese which is really good though not traditional. This place is a sad imitation of the real thing.   Tourist trap.

Kind of like Disney.... expensive, loud, full of people, big furniture and decorations, with semi-attentive staff waiting for large tips. The food is Americanized German food (pretty good) and the appeal is purchasing one liter of beer and seeing people dance on tables. I'm not sold on this.  However, I'd like to try the sauerkraut balls and potato pancakes, and pretzels,with other beers. Beer selection is authentic and plentiful.

Normally, Hofbrauhaus is known amongst college students for its Thursday night beer deals during College Night (9-11 PM). However, I had a college departmental graduation dinner here and was pleasantly surprised by the food as well. As German food isn't know to be the most vegetarian-friendly, I was apprehensive about what my entree options would be. However, there were more vegetarian options than expected, including multiple appetizers, salads, pasta, and garden burger.  For my appetizer, the pretzel and salads complemented each other well. In particular, the pretzel was warm and soft when served and went well with the accompanying mustard. For the main entree, I got the Kaespatzle, which is a pasta with cream sauce, cheese and onions. This dish was slightly heavy and wasn't as flavorful as I was expecting - the first couple bites were good but then the flavors felt a bit monotonous. Dessert included an Apple Strudel and Chocolate Stout cake, both very scrumptious. Overall, its worth a shot to check out the food here, in addition to the beer.

When the whole crew loves a place it is a huge win.   German food was great (Gulaschsuppe, Schnitzel, Weiss Wurst, cabbage, pierogies), local food was also good (Pittsburg Salad), and their take on other foods (nachos) were just terrific.   Did not try the beer but would go out of our way to come here for the food.

My husband and I went here for a family party while we were in Pittsburgh over Thanksgiving.  We loved it!    We came in the afternoon because we thought it would be really difficult to get a table at night.   We were a party of 18.   First off  there is every beer imaginable.  You can get the 1 liter stein and purchase it or get a regular size mug.   They also have a full bar.   My husband got the large stein.purchased it.  We both got the 3 brats with saurkrat and potatoes but I substituted a potato pancake for the mashed potatoes.  They bring a basket of large pretzels with bier cheese to start.  The food is good, but it's the atmosphere that makes it fun.   We got there too early for the band, but they had an accordian player there who kept things lively by taking requests for toasts and offfering toasts.  It was a fun afternoon,

When I used to drink beer, this would be the place to get a good one. Make sure you load up on carbs before you go to the place. Otherwise, you may get extremely drunk from the liters and pints. The view from the restaurant is really spectacular. The river and the crowd are unbeatable.

This place was great.  I wasn't expecting the food to be good or to find much activity on a late Thursday night. I walked in (after a visit to REI) and found a seat right away.  Within 45 minutes, though, there was a big crowd, people were dancing on the tables and there was a great, fun environment. And, the food WAS delicious!

OK so I went here late at night at about 12 am on a Friday night right after checking out the Interview over at the theater across the st.  The security of this place is absolutely crazy, which makes sense given that when we went all the college kids were off from school, meaning party time.... which is basically what we walked into after showing our IDs to the bouncer. By this time the restaurant area was blocked off and it was just the main bar - beer hall area. They had a cover band playing what you would expect a band to play at a frat party all while wearing leaderhosen.  Most of the patrons were standing on benches and dancing around. Which in a way was kind of unexpected as I would think they stand when singing drinking songs not, Neil Diamon or AC/DC.   Anyway, we walked on to the bar and waited a few to put in our beer order. While waiting one of the patrons tried to cut in front of us, but fortunately the bartender noted this and totally blew the guy off for a bit. Also prior to making our drink order, the bartender asked once again for our ID. Given the high number of college/possibly HS kids I totally got it... and also felt bad for the wait staff as a lot of the patrons seemed just so douchey.  We got our beer right away which was delicious... what you would expect from Hofbrauhaus. Now as we were enjoying our beer we enjoyed the people watching, which was quite entertaining.    After our one beer, we left, as it definitely is not a place for conversation. More of a place to get trashed. Now, I really don't know if this is the normal scene, but I was not that impressed. I will also say we didn't try any of their food, which is something we plan to do when it gets warmer as they have really nice outdoor seating overlooking the river.

I love going to this restaurant, they have a lot of great outside dining available right along side the river so its a great view!   I prefer the outside dining to inside because it gets very loud inside, its hard to hold a conversation.  Great German food dishes , and for someone that doesnt like German food they also have some american food like hamburgers.  Great for beer lovers, too!

I have been here several times in both warm and cool/ cold months. This is a large space that on weekends can feel very cramped.   Atmosphere - 20, 30, 40 somethings, girl vs guy ratio 2 - 4, frat house, noisy, crowded, massive, messy, spills on your favorite shirt, the majority of people arriving in groups.   Service - Again, it is like a frat house here on the weekends. So service here consists of pushing your way to the bar and sticking your money out to let them know you are ready to order. Summers here are a bit better. The outside bar, which faces the river, has easier access.   Prices - The prices are a bit on the higher side for it being in the SouthSide. Mixed drinks are around $7 and beers around $5 and up.   Food - The beer is decent here, I usually get the Hefe Weizen. I am not the biggest beer drinker so I usually switch to Cap'n and Cokes. I have never eaten here (other than a pretzel) as it is always too crowded. I think the less crowded and less rowdy afternoons are probably a better time to try out their food.   Overall - While I have never had a blast here, as I feel I am getting too old to go, I think the best time to go to the Hofbrauhaus is in the summer months. This is because you can escape the craziness of the main area (lodge?) and head to the bottom level to really enjoy some time down by the river.
Love this place! Great atmosphere, live music, good beer and delicious food! An unexpected find on our trip to Pittsburgh.. and we were pleasantly surprised!
Fun, lively place.  Loud but fun! Great German food.  We love coming here when we visit Pitt!

When you're in the mood for some Kitschy-coup, this is definitely the place for you!  I've not been into 'theme parks' for a very long time. Their appeal wore off when they became totally commercialized pre-fab 'facades' of 'fun'. I also lost my tastes for malls years ago when they robbed our country of that hometown real main street experience, and the demise of mom and pop businesses. To me, places like the South Side Works, and the businesses contained therein really aren't much different than a mall attempt at 'themeing' the small town neighborhood business strip at a theme park. Like Disney's 'Small Town USA' - pretty, painted 'sets' with the same ol' chains disguised as 'unique'.  For the holiday, my neighbors and I headed out for something 'different', for a Christmas eve day lunch, and thanks to an Amazon special deal of the day, we ended up in pseudo Bavaria in the pseudo mall/pseudo small town America village that used to be an actual source of viable income for the local 'steel' community.  Fun for a couple of hours when you're in the mood for the Germany beer hall ride, complete with the oom-pa-pa music and sing alongs. Only there are no worries about keeping your arms inside the car, and securing your safety bar.  Now, I must admit, where most places that attempt to 'theme' something in the burgh usually fall flat on their faces, Hofbrau Haus hits the nail on the head, and takes it ALL the way, from the decor, to the menu, the santa-in-lederhosen one man band, and the gals with the push up bras that make their cleavage appear on the verge of exploding.   The menu is ALL German. Now, having grown up with German as a part of my ethnic heritage, that variety of Eastern European food has never been a favorite. The very smell of fried cabbage was enough to make me gag, and I just kind of grew up to appreciate a wider variety of flavors and spices. I only had one relative who WAS a good cook, and even she lost me on halushki. (her side was more slovak than German).  Now, all of that being said...Hofbrau Haus WAS a somewhat fun escape for an afternoon, and the food WAS pretty good, albeit a tad pricey (just a tad, not excruciatingly).  For three adults and one child, we split the appetizer platter, which contained fresh made pretzels, fried pickles, fried Sauerkraut balls, and a large potato pancake, accompanied by honey mustard, ranch dressing, applesauce and Bier Cheese as dipping sauces. It was plentiful, tasty, and unique in the flavor combos.  I had a hard time choosing from the entrees. Every time I read the ingredient lists I cringed when I saw 'fried cabbage', or onions in any way, shape, or form. At first I was flip flopping between a burger and something called the Hofbrau Hot Brown, which was turkey and ham served on a potato pancake topped with swiss cheese, homemade bier cheese, tomato, bacon and parmesan cheese -  and then everyone pointed out that I could get a burger anywhere (and frankly, why kitsch it up, when the real thing is at Winghart's?), so then it became a flip flop between the Hot brown and the Hofbrauhaus Wurstlplatte which was grilled bierwurst, bratwurst, and frankfurter served with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.  I ended up opting for the Hot brown based on price.  My neighbors got the Heidelberger Rahm Spatzle - Pulled Chicken And Spatzle sauteed with caramelized onions and field mushrooms tossed into a marsala cream sauce, and a wurst dish that was kind of similar in ingredients to the hot brown. For the little one, well, pizza and fries, of course.  The Hot Brown arrived, and although it was a LOT smaller than I expected it to be, it really was very tasty. VERY cheesey creamy. Much larger in portion, so much so that my neighbor couldn't eat it all, thus allowing for extras to be passed around, the Spatzle was yummy too, though I did regret the onions later.   They each had some kind of funky beer, which would never appeal to me (beer just reminds me of recreational drinkers, red necks and frat boys), and though I opted for Diet Coke, they were Pepsi people, so I ended up with iced tea.  There were drinking songs being sung in addition to the holiday songs, with glasses clanking and a few hoots and hollers (and yodels) here and there, adding to a kind of mish-mash of holiday revelry and plain ol' beer hall drinking revelers. At 2 in the afternoon, however, there wasn't any dancing on tables.  The service staff was very capable and helpful, from the man who greeted us at the front door, to the waitress who took care of us.  All in all, it was a quite pleasant escape from 'the usual'. I just can't say it's an escape I'd add to my calendar for a regular visit though. It would indeed be a rare craving for this kind of amusement park atmosphere, for a guy with a not-so-strong desire for German food OR beer. But, again, that being said - even the guy who doesn't have a taste for any of that managed to have an enjoyable afternoon and meal, with good company

Excellent beer selection and food in a giant German beer hall. What's not to like?   The pretzels, apple potato pancakes, and fried sauerkraut balls were especially good. The grilled brat with sauerkraut is worth getting as well.   The service might be a little slow but you're enjoying the beer hall so don't stress too much.

Ah the things we do for husbands. Like most guys, my husband wanted nothing more for his birthday than to sit around eating carb loaded foods with a huge stein of beer in front of him. This place did not disappoint.  We went on a Saturday night around 6:30 and we walked right up to the hostess stand. No joke though. Two minutes later I turned around and the line was out the door. This place was PACKED.   We were seated pretty promptly and were lucky enough to score one of the booths that flank the main hall. PERFECT seating to watch the debauchery.   The menu is pretty much what you expect. I've been to HB Munich, and this place wasn't much difference. One HUGE difference though. This German girl did not appreciate that the schnitzel was pork not veal.   Service was great despite the ridiculous amount of people in there. There was some sort of ski contraption that people were taking shots from. Provides more and more amusement as the night goes on!   There was a guy singing actual German music for most of the evening. Once it got later though the band came on. They play cover songs. Strangely enough quite authentic as Germans LOVE our cover songs.  The place also has a little shop to buy souvenirs inside in case you want to buy some HB souvenirs.

I absolutely love this place. The amazing beer brewed in house, the authentic food, the stage music. Everything.  I stopped in on my long drive home from Thanksgiving since I knew I would be driving through Pittsburgh. So glad I did!  I started with some warm, soft pretzels and beer cheese and a half litre of Dunkel (a house brew) that never fails to be delicious. Then went with the Bavarian platter for two that included some delicious sauerkraut, spatzle, schnitzel, fried cabbage, pork loin, and wursts! Overall a very nice spread and everything was extremely satisfying.   Typically though based on past experiences I would favor the Jagerschnitzel. It's deeeelicious.   The real winner of this whole experience though is the dessert. Apple strudel that is so to-die for. Warm, perfectly sweet and satisfying. This is the one thing you HAVE to try if you are coming here.   Hofbrauhaus is an amazing German experience you have to try!

Accessible parking.  The restaurant feels sterile, even though the decor is Bavarian.  It's too quiet for a place called Hofbrauhaus.  Nevertheless, the beer is fresh and it was a great place to stop on a hot afternoon in Pittsburgh.

I absolutely love the environment in this place. People go here to be loud and have fun. The outside seating is great and the big hall is s great experience.   If you want to hold a conversation with people and chit-chat...not the place for you.   Beer: I just ordered one without asking questions first...mistake, maybe the first time in my life I ordered a beer and just refused to drink it. I learned after that they have a sampler, if you are not sure, try the sampler first. It will save you some trouble.   So my review for this place is mixed, IF you are looking for a loud place where people are having a good time with good food, do it, I just caution you to sample the beers before ordering a whole stein.

We just came for a beer and to try the pretzels and beer cheese, always a must for a German spot. The cheese tastes less like a german beer cheese and more like nacho cheese sauce, and I also wish it had mustard. All that said, it's still very tasty and hit the spot. They only have a hand-full of beers available, too bad, but there were some good ones in the mix. The best part is that they have a monthly rotating selection. I had to give it a try, and for August they offered the sommerweizer. It had that german beer flavor, just what I was looking for.   The real reason to visit this place is the huuuge outdoor terrace, with an upper section with waiter service and a lower picnic table area with drinking along the river. Really nice vibe and great views. Inside is also huge, totally different vibe with loud, live German music. The only real downside is that it is located a bit off from the main Carson Street stretch, about a ten-twelve minute walk from the rest of the Southside bars. Still, a cool spot worth a visit.

Gotta love the liter dunkels.  The food is decent depending on what you get. I feel like the pretzels and beer cheese are a little over-hyped. The schintzel sandwich is probably my favorite thing to eat there.  The place has a live band that usually plays good sing along songs (you are encouraged to stand on the benches but please don't stand on the table)  The shotskis are a fun thing to do with a group (expensive but where else do you get to take a shot off of a ski?)  All in all a good spot to hang out and chill. Once spring/summer rolls around the outside bier garden is a great place to just relax with a liter of beer and shoot the shit with your friends.

I could sit here and eat the beer cheese for 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. It is the absolute best you will find anywhere!!! Put it on EVERYTHING, because why not???  I ordered a pork chop and smothered it. It made an average chop out of this world!  I'm pretty sure I have to limit my visits here so I don't gain 100 pounds from cheese overload
Appetizers were really good. Chicken was good but thick cut. Live music was great one of the best atmospheres in south side. Right on the river and great service.

PROS- Amazing food, great beer/ale choices, wonderful service along with a cozy Interior and a fantastic deck.  CONS- Too many out of control college kids who can't handle their alcohol consumption.   Recommendations: You must get the pretzels and secret sauce that comes with it. Get the jaeger schnitzel.  Get a kraner wurst also sehr gut. Get a stein. Get a side of red cabbage and kraut.  The interior is decorated in a warm old-school German tavern style.  The service is prompt and polite. The tap has a number of German ales/beer to choose from (all delicious and served in rather German ceramic mugs or tall pilsner glasses ) The food is incredible. I started with a beef goulash soup that had bursting flavors for my taste buds.  I always buy my jaeger schnitzel which is always cooked perfect with a savory dark mushroom gravy on top.    Lastly, sit outside and enjoy the panoramic views of the river.

This is a must stop if in Pittsburgh.  Great pretzel, plenty of beer to choose from.  The only thing I wasn't able to do was go here on a weekend night.  I was there on a Monday before a Pirates game.  Not many people there.  Great location, right on the water.  Friendly staff.  Seats 800 and I was told they get to standing room only on the weekends.

Good food, good beer, and the staff was pleasant. A little pricey, but on-par for a theme restaurant, I suppose. No complaints at all. It was ~25 degrees outside, but the enclosed patio was a comfortable temperature. Our server seemed to be somewhat new, but wasn't bad at all. The "Christmasbier" was addictive, as was the Hot Brown and Pretzels with Beer Cheese. Not sure why Yelp states "not good for kids" in earlier reviews. It's a little loud, but was enjoyable; our 8 and 12-year olds had a good time.

If you want to really enjoy a real German beer hall experience, come visit Hofbrauhaus on weekends when the place is packed with people. Excellent energy and vibe!  If you want to really appreciate how good and attentive the service, how huge the space both interior and exterior (patios overlooking the river, what a view!!), come visit Hofbrauhaus during weekdays.   Come visit Hofbrauhaus whenever and you will guarantee a good time!  Great beers, love my Hefeweizen and our Wurst platter - Bratwurst, Wiesswurst and Frankfurter ($13.99) was surprisingly good!   Sausage Feast! Beer serves in Stein!   Prost!

Came here yesterday and we are back already. Really wish they had a spot in NJ or philly. There hefeweizen beer is delicious and light. They serve beer by the liter in huge steins. Anywho I had two beers and could of had a few (the baby size not the liter ). We had the cheese fries to start and not many places have cheese sauce at the bottom (why? I have no clue). So there was an endless supply of cheese. Apparently you can upgrade to put chili on top to make them like nachos. I was going for more of a marathon not a sprint so I opted out. Anyway, I ordered the hot brown with a fried egg on it. Apparently that's the way to do it, and I would agree that it is. It's a potato pancake with ham, turkey, bacon and egg with cheese on cheese on cheeses. It made me feel like . We had the pretzels with cheese too, so as you can imagine, I felt like I would die later. Thankfully I didn't so I could come back today!

All I can say is, LOVED This place when I lived in Pittsburgh. Can't wait to visit the St. Petersburg location. So happy there is one here in Florida.    I suggest any of the authentic German options, which are indicated on the menu. I get the roasted half chicken, then ask for different sides, I love the red cabbage and beer cheese spatzle. The German potato salad, the potato dumpling, and the fried cabbage are also amazing.   Planning on trying the potato pancake and pierogies when I can.

I know, I know..... This is a chain.    I have been to the hofbrau in Germany.   While everything is based on this restaurant, I prefer the Pittsburgh version.   Service is always so much better.    While the pretzels are clearly better in Germany, the food and beer are on par.   I am a fan of schnitzel with hefe wiezen beer.    I get the liter because it is my favorite.   The down side to this place is it is extremely loud.....   So keep this in mind....
Good Pretzel! As good as the one I had in Germany! The atmosphere during their busy time feels like the one in Munich! Servers carry their own change wallet just like in Europe.

Brought my family (group of 9) here for a nice dinner on the patio- great idea! They can accommodate large groups and there is plenty of beer to go around! The atmosphere is true to what you would find over in Germany- loud and boisterous! If you're not into loud music and chanting- sit on the patio- you'll be glad you did! The view is spectacular!  The food was also nice- ordered schnitzel sandwich and potato pancakes.

Went here on St. Patrick's Day so it was CROWDED. There are 2 dining areas and one is like a big hall with a stage. The other one through French doors is as roomy but a lot quieter.  Our party ordered a wurst dish and 2 shnitzel dishes. Shnitzel can be pretty dry so definitely go for the dishes that come with sauce! Taste is great and portions were reasonable but not too large (unfortunately). I like that all the waitresses were in German outfits. Management and staff were nice. One staff member cleared the way to the private bathroom with a changing table for my baby through the drunken crowd so I really appreciated that!   Location is cool because it's right next to the riverfront trail. I'm thinking we'll be back in the summer or spring! Prices for entrees are between $16 - $28 so a little on the high side. No free bread or pretzels :(. I got the apple strudel dessert and while the presentation was beautiful, the taste of the pastry was bland and soggy. I probably should have gone for the cream puff like I planned!

Ahh so kitsch. The food is a step or two better than the meals at Ikea but their beer is pretty darn good and can easily tip a lightweight like me. I especially like that it's a place where all of Pittsburgh comes. Not just the college peeps. I see very large (in more than one sense of the word), and extended families enjoying time without the kids here, 20 somethings, and a group of people from my school. Again, I just go for the beer and I end up having a good time. It's one of the few restaurants that take advantage of the riverfront and for that I'm eternally grateful.

Hofbrauhaus is like Oktoberfest at Disneyland, it's an experience and fun, but if you look too closely you can tell it's a corporate entity. Does that make sense? I guess I've been spoiled, in terms of German food by Max's Allegheny Tavern, and my own Grandmother, because I've found the food at Hofbrauhaus passable at best. If you want a truly German food experience you'll find Hofbrau watered down, and if you're not into German food, but like the idea of a German Beer House then get the baby back ribs.  Okay, maybe the above was harsh, but in general I enjoy the beer and sitting in the beer garden during the summer. It's great to look out on the river have a liter or two of their Premium Lager and get some pretzels and cheese sauce. All in all, when I'm at South Side works looking to kill a few hours with some day drinking Hofbrauhaus has my back. Also, it's a great place to bring your country mouse cousin when they're in town.

This place was ridiculously awesome. As soon as I walked in, I saw people standing on benches singing and dancing. I wish we stayed inside longer, but we walked right through to the back and went outside where there were tons of tables right on the river.  It was pretty crowded, but the bar was so big that waiting to get drinks wasn't an issue and we didn't have a problem finding a table. The bartenders were friendly and quick. I ordered a laaarge Dunkel for $7.50. Their bathrooms were clean and huge, which is always a plus for me (no lines!).  It's great that you can be rowdy inside or chill outside. Definitely trying to stop in here next time I'm in Pittsburgh!

LOVE this place. I had such a fun time there and I don't even drink beer. The cocktails are pretty good. The bartenders can make pretty much anything. They had some good food there as well. The table dancing was my favorite part of my night there.

I like this place. On a summer day I like the patio and balcony overlooking the Monongahela with the breeze off the river.  I like the cold, sharp, crisp beers. I like the fun, live German bands inside. I even like the Disney-esque German uniforms the waitstaff wears.  What I don't like about this place is the food.  I love sauerkraut, with "sauer" being the key part of that word. The kraut here lacks the sauer.  The sausages are bland.  The chicken dishes are bland.  Even the beer cheese is pretty dang bland.    The two best things I've found?  The pretzels with mustard (just regular ol' yellow mustard), and the salads, which are big with just the right amount of crunchy iceberg and romaine mixed with just the right amount of flavorful green leaves from other lettuces.  I'm not saying they're the best salads around, but they're better than anything else on the menu.

Wifey and I went to Hofbräuhaus for our annual summer visit.  I've been here a handful of times at night but we like the outside seating and it get's so busy at night.   It's not the best experience for us at night here.  So a few years back we came her during the day and it was great.  So when we visit Hofbräuhaus we usually come here early afternoon so we can soak up the sun, enjoy each other, take some cool pictures of us outside, and drinks some liters of beer!       I'm a wheat beer type of guy so I'm in heaven when I am here.  I'll drink their Hefe Weizen any time of the year but it' summer so I had their "Sommer Weizen".  This is just a great summer wheat beer.  Smooth, great color, great summer taste that is very enjoyable.  I wouldn't drink this one all year round if it was offered like the original Hefe Weizen but it's great for the summer.         Our favorite seasonal beer here no doubt is their HB Oktoberfest.  I would drink this one all year round.  We were a little early for this one because it should be available in September.  I hope we can find sometime to come back for that or I'll just have to pick some up at a store no doubt.       My rating is purely for the beer and the day time setting outside.  The bartenders and service was good.  I like the restrooms and they are clean.  Don't get me wrong about the night life here.  I like it here at night but it's too busy for us.  Were getting older we need some more peace and you can find that during the day.  We have never eaten any food here so I can't rate that but it's always tempting.  We just usually throw back a few here, take some cool pics of us drinking a liter of beer, and then we go to dinner somewhere else.         Come here on a warm sunny day, sit outside, get a liter of beer and you will have a great time here at Hofbräuhaus Pittsburgh!

If a large crowd of people standing on benches at long tables in a beer hall, dancing and waving gigantic mugs of German brew back and forth as they listen to a cheesy cover band is your idea of a good time, then Hofbrauhaus is the place for you.   I have a soft spot for a place where everyone is encouraged to party, and this place is just that. We went there on a Saturday night on a recent trip to Pittsburgh and the place was jam-packed and everyone was having fun.   The place is a little "white" ethnically speaking, music-wise, etc. The live band played old cover songs you'd probably hear at weddings, e.g., Neil Diamond, Billy Joel, etc.  You will find yourself singing along.   Beer is brewed there, and is good and cheap -- the  liters were about $8. The wheat beer was nice, so was the lager.  We didn't have the food, so I can't comment on that.  Go with a group of friends. It's a fun place!

Beer Mugs that could crack a skull, check. German band with an accordion, check. Hostesses wearing Dirndl-s? that accentuates their majors in upper body asset management, check. Huge open dining room wit over sized tables and benches, check.  Everything at Hofbraushaus seemed larger than life including the patrons standing on their chairs and downing shots to the chants led by the band.  Our meal was more of a feast including a soft pretzel apps with bier cheese rich enough kill you and the old timer seated at the bar. For my entree I order the wiener schnitzel with steamed vegetables and German potato salad. The pork was fried perfectly and was both juicy and crispy and could easily last 2 meals. The potato salad had a nice balance of spice and was light on the mustard and mayo relative to picnic potato salads. It was a struggle to finish both my meal and my beer, but hey, I'm on vacation. Overindulgence is mandatory.

Been here numerous times this is my favorite stop when I get to go to Pittsburgh. The food and beers are good, the atmosphere is excellent, and the staff are always very friendly and accommodating. We normally will take a fairly nice size crowd with us when we go here and it is always accommodated perfectly. I have not found anything on the menu so far that I did not like.

Great pretzels and beer cheese! I am not a huge fan of their other food, but the soft pretzels definitely make up for where the menu may be lacking. Hofbrauhaus also has a great atmosphere and is tons of fun. I definitely recommend to anyone in the Southside Works area!

I had my first beer ever here at Hofbrauhaus! I love the atmosphere of the expansive beer hall. Live music was fun, and who doesn't want to clank mugs of beer together while standing on tables? It does get very busy late night and service can get slow, but it's all part of the experience :-) I highly recommend this place; don't leave without having the pretzels and a shotski!

I cannot emphasize enough how awesome this place is. Traditional German beer hall. The food is outstanding, I've never had a bad meal. The bier cheese needs to be tried.   Beer, let's be honest, this is why you come here. Two sizes, liter (as big as your head), half liter. All brewed on premise. 4 always on tap (my favorite is the Dunkel) and a monthly beer.   The staff is also a blast. From the rocking house band, to the polite wait staff, to the imposing security, everyone is nice as can be. Get up and jam. You can dance on the benches until your legs can't hold you up, but stay off the tables.   I recommend this as a stop anytime you visit Pittsburgh. When you are there, ask for Big Andy and tell him Neil said hi.

I can't say enough about this place! Authentic German cuisine, but also a variety of dishes with an American twist. It took me an hour to decide what to order because there were so many great dishes on the menu. The service was outstanding. Our server, Dana, was friendly, funny, and helpful. Her recommendations were right on and she was very attentive.  This is the best restaurant I've experienced in a very long time.

Decor is 10/10 and so is the beer but the food is garbage. I thought they were going to sell legit Bavarian food because some of it is imported. They managed to even Americanize the pretzel. The giant pretzel was nothing like a Bavarian pretzel- it was a glorified philly pretzel. I am not a pretzel elitist but they don't got the food down. A Bavarian pretzel is dark brown, borderline black, matte, and a lot denser. This was soft and fluffy and the cheese sauce was pretty much a less tangy cheese whiz.   The warm potato salad was garbage - slices were undercooked and seasoned all wrong. The use of food service thin sliced American bacon in the fried cabbage did the dish no favors because it comes off as pre-rendered so the fat didn't lend itself to the dish, instead you had these sad, floppy slices of bacon to suggest the miserable life the pig had. I know you have to adapt to the resources around you but it detracted from the dish. Cabbage was completely unremarkable.   The ultimate abomination was the schnitzel itself. The texture was spongy. It was disconcerting to why a cutlet had that texture. And it was not remotely crunchy for something deep fried which made it even worse. This my friend, is not a schnitzel. The wine mushroom sauce for the jaegerschnitzel was not rich and meaty like a real German gravy but was thin and flavorless like something out of a package.   This food was essentially mediocre theme park (a la Dixieland) "German" food and I'm confused why was it so mediocre when German food is probably the safest "ethnic" food and arguably has the most influence on American food overall (hot dogs, burgers).   For the love of Gött, HB Pittsburgh, make authentic and GOOD Bavarian food for the prices you charge or lower them if you're going to cut corners.   Silver lining is that the beer is solid and served at the right temperature. You wouldn't be able to tell the difference between this pint and one you got in a Biergarten in Munich.

The beer is good but the food is average. I had their light lager. I had the Bier cheese chicken and it reminded me of Fridays sizzling chicken and cheese-which is actually better at Fridays (and cheaper). Had the pretzels for an app and they were just like any other pretzel. The place was packed so I must be missing something. Parking was a nightmare. Just not worth the hassle to me. They really cram everyone in there. They had live music which was cool. Got there at 4 and had an hour wait on a Saturday. You can't make reservations.
The people here were really nice. I think they take some slack for the outfits, but they were still very kind.   Oh, and the beer is great...

I'm partial to Hofbrau only in the summer....in the winter, it gets too cooped up, and I really can't stand the obnoxiously drunk singing inside.  I'm sure some people love it, but it's just not me.  I've spent a lot of time at this place, and you should definitely go here if you haven't been here, just be prepared for LOUD.   I highly recommend you go in the summer and head straight for the back...the downstairs patio outside is a great way to spend a summer evening.  A year ago I probably would have given them 5 stars, but nothing has changed and it gets stale after a while.  If you haven't been here though,  you should absolutely go...there's a reason there are so many reviews.    As far as food, I echo Rachel's sentiment:  TGIFridays but with German food.  The food doesn't do it for me.  Definitely a drinking spot only.    On to the things I do like...the 1L of wheat beer, and the beer cheese + pretzels.  You should get a liter of beer because, well, you can't get it in many other places.  And yes, it is brewed in haus.

We had dinner a couple of weeks ago before going to the Phipps winter show. The dinner was excellent, my husband had Weisswürste and I had the Schnitzel Wiener Art both was very delicious just like we had dinner in Germany. We also had dessert I had the Apple strudel with ice cream and my husband had the cream puff both was very good. Beer was also very good we tried the beer sampler, can`t wait until we come again!!

People like to complain that the food is not the most authentic, but that is not why you go here, you go for the food, the shotski and the ambiance.  If you took time to stop complaining about how authentic the food is, you would realize that the food they have is actually pretty darned good.  I have always enjoyed their schnitzels.  The shank is very good.  THe apple desert is delicious.  And you can not beat the singing!
Cheap, good beer.  Large portions of great food.    Women in those outfits... yowza!!  I go there for the beer and the food though, not the ladies, but the ladies are a nice addition....

Deafeningly loud with an insanely long wait, the Hofbrauhaus is a victim of its own success.  I really enjoyed the food (I had the spaetzel entree, and shared the sampler appetizers with our table -- the sauerkraut balls were a surprise for someone who doesn't even like sauerkraut!) and the beer (custom brewed), but can't imagine going back until the shine's off the apple and Pittsburghers have moved on to the next big thing.    Great spot to do heavy drinking, though -- the "shot-ski" was a popular choice at the tables around us, and every time one came out, it commanded the attention of the whole hall.

I had steak at a German restaurant. I wasn't in a German food mood really. My steak was good, surprisingly. The mashed potatoes were amazing. My husband had the pork shank and it was gone before I could taste. They have live music every day. I can see it getting rowdy here with the raising beer pitchers and German chanting. Also walking distance from the Hyatt house and Spring hill suites.

I know this kind of a tourist trap/spot for the suburbanites because of its location and other things but I still like coming here. The food is always good and the beers. Well, the beers are out of this world.

A great taste of Americanized Germany without taking a trip overseas.  If you like getting drunk as F, drinking 1L beers, eating loads of food, and staring at bewbs, this is the place for you. The nice-looking waitstaff doesn't provide the best service ever, but how can you complain about cleavage popping out everywhere? That's what I thought. Suck it up and suck it down.

Hofbrauhaus is definitely in my top 5 favorite restaurants! I haven't been to the original but for Pittsburgh, they do a great job. The only real inconvenience is the wait time on the weekends. Also, I've unfortunately noticed the service being not as great in the outside section. But the unique atmosphere and the big beers as well as the excellent service inside the bar & dining area makes it totally worthwhile! There is a cute little gift shop inside. This is my go to for authentic German cuisine and a traditional German experience. You could make a nice evening out of coming here and not be disappointed.

This review is only for the beer and experience. Hofbrauhaus is huge and fun if you are there with a big group. The beer is tasty, especially the lager and dunkel.  IMO the hefeweizen is a bit heavy with the banana and clove but perhaps that's how a true hefeweizen  should taste like.   I get annoyed inside with repetitions of living on a prayer, sweet caroline, sweet home alabama and steelers fight songs so I'm almost always outside. The people there eat it up but having already experiencing four years of drunk idiots singing journey, experiencing it again is nauseating.   The kids are young, Many 21 year olds chose this place to celebrate their coming of age. But really the clientel ranges from these 21 year olds to 80 year olds attempting to get jiggy with it.   Outside is very nice, ample seating and nice views.  Its a great pace to take visitors to see something they can't see everywhere.   Overall, a place to go with friends to enjoy a beer before heading somewhere else or a place to linger all night if that's your thang.    Like tanqueray, hofbrauhaus is good only in moderation.

Went here to break Passover this year  What we sampled:   Beer sampler       Definitely a good way to try different beers, to get an idea of what you like. I was really interested in the Hefeweizen with flavors of banana and clove.  It was definitely interesting smelled like bananas and tasted like cloves.  Appetizer sample      The beer cheese and pretzels were great and the sauerkraut balls were definitely interesting.  I wasn't such a big fan of the potato pancakes though.  Beer Cheese spatzel      Total winner of the night.  It was awesome.  Apple Streudel      A classic, though I don't know if I would order it again.  Not really my thing.   Service was great and helpful!

Every time I come to Pittsburgh, I make sure to go to Hofbrauhaus! For any German beer fan who has been living under a rock, Hofbrauhaus is a German Biergarten in Munich.  Each time I come to Hofbrauhaus, I make sure to try one of their seasonal beers. So far, I have tried the Weizenbock, Bavarian Wheat and the Marzen. Outside of this, I have tried most of their other beers with the Weizen being my favorite. The great thing about the Hofbrauhaus in Pittsburgh is the fact that they brew their beers there! This means you will always get a fresh beer!  As for the food; the food is always great! It's a little expensive; however, the portions are huge! When I go, I always split the Schmankerlplatte with someone. This plate consists of Schweinsbraten, Smoked Pork Chops, three kinds of Wursts, Sauerkraut, Fried Cabbage, and Mashed Potatoes. It's huge! Everything on it is great!  My only complaint with this place is the lack of parking; however, this is an issue pretty much anywhere you go in Pittsburgh.

I have to give this place a split personality review.  The party side of me says this place is a heck of a good time!  The foodie side of me says this place compares to a TGIFridays, but with German food.   The first time I came here was right after they opened....so I wanted to come for the food and drink.  It was the dead of winter so the outdoor area wasn't open yet and we were shoved in the corner of the large dining room.  I couldn't decide what to order because I love sauerkraut, I love cabbage and I love German Potato Salad!  It's sad I didn't even want any of the meats, all sides!  So I just stuck to those and apps.  I mean who can go wrong with those choices??   So the fried pickles were good and....fried.  Check.  The sauerkraut was like mush.  Ew.  I expect good sauerkraut from a German place!  I want it crisp and tart.  Just plain mush.  The German Potato salad, mushy as well.  Potato's, mushy....no flavor.  Yuck.  Fried Cabbage...you hear me....FRIED....was mush!  Seriously, horrible!  I would never come here to eat again.    On the other side....   Atmosphere is fantastic! The dining room is really rambunctious! They have people standing on tables and singing.  they have a HUGE shot luge where a bunch of people have to take shots at once.  And the outside...FANTASTIC!  It's this huge open area with picnic tables and a large bar.  Plus you're right smack against the river so it's really pretty out to.  Pretty for a beer garden I suppose!  The beer comes in these huge liters, which is great in theory, but if you're not slamming them back it gets warm and nasty.  I'm always a lager fan, so I had the Hofbräu Premium Lager.  It was pretty much lager like.  Nothing to write home to Germany about.   So remember, food gross but drinking atmosphere GREAT!

My husband is convinced they make the most delicious lager in town; so nothing makes him happier than a trip to Hofbrauhaus for a liter. I tend to agree, though I go more for the spaetzle and schnitzel.   I personally think their beer is better than than the food. Their brewers are awesome! For good ole' German fare, I prefer the schnitzels at Max's Tavern or the menu at Penn Brewery, esp when they break out the Penn Oktoberfest. But at Hofbraus, there is something very special and festive about the Great Hall with the accordion player or the magically lit biergarten on warm summer nights that makes it an easy choice for any kind of beer and pretzel hankering. Located off the bike trail in the South Side Works area, it is very easily accessible by bike or boat with the new addition of the marina.   We like to try their monthly food and beer pairings as they are usually very good and off menu.  They will let you sample the different beers before you commit to a liter or half liter which is nice.  It is a huge space with plenty of seating inside and out, making it an easy meet up place for family and friends.

I was not impressed.  The beer wasn't very good (I tried the amber one, it tasted like the keg lines hadn't been cleaned in a while).  The whole place smells like a fart.  The worst part was that the doormen were really rude.  My wife's id was hole-punched because she is getting a new one because her name is changing.  Even though she is clearly older than 21 (she's 26) they wouldn't let her drink.  Not a huge deal, they were just following the law.  But they proceeded to assign staff to watch us the entire night.  A greasy ogre literally followed us around and watched to make sure she wasn't drinking.

My husband and I were excited to go here for the first time. I reserved a table through Yelp no waitlist. It worked great. We walked through the door they were tons of people waiting in line and I was able to go to the front of the line and get seated right away. However they seated us on the enclosed patio, where it was cold. The restaurant was extremely busy, so I don't hold this against them. But it took forever for food. The food left a lot to be desired.This place is known for their beers, however of the long list of beers none of them were available. Only had a choice of three beers. $80 later plus tip we left. As we walked through the main room, it looked like people were having fun. But unfortunately we didn't get to have any fun out on the patio. I don't think we will be back anytime soon. If you do go, wait to be seated in the main room, Expect to sit with strangers, and don't go there when you're famished.

Hofbrauhaus is not for me.  They have tasty sandwiches (pretzel sandwich!), pretzels and beer cheese, and--of course--beer. The Dunkel is the best of the regular options, to my taste.    I'm not into the whole concept-- the canned, Disney-version-of-Bavaria with Oompa accordion music, waitresses in skimpy outfits, drunk people standing on communal tables, kitschy sing-alongs, mega-sized TV screens with all the sports events blaring-- just no. The noise and the crowds mean that you need to go there for the express purpose of enjoying the aforementioned other stuff.  There's no doubt it's a fun place; it's just that Hofbrauhaus is not my idea of fun.   I feel a bit bad about writing a critical review without suggestions for improvement, as it's the whole corporate concept that's not to my taste.  The point of this review is to suggest that there are so many better options for grown ups to drink a beer in Pittsburgh, especially if conversation is a goal.  If watching sports, singing, and getting smashed are goals, then you might have a heck of a fun time.

In town for one night from DC and had a great time.  Food was decent but the beer, music and ambiance was part of what made this a great time for my wife and me.   The  best part of our visit though was the service - Kelsey was so helpful, so much fun and so doggone good at her job that even if the ambiance had "sucked" I'd make it a point to come back again. Thank you Kelsey- it was a tough night for us and you made it a lot of fun.  We are very grateful.
Great lively atmosphere!  Traditional food and beer.  Our meals were spot on as well as the delicious desserts.  Make sure you add ice cream!

We are fans of the original Hofbrauhaus in Munich.  Yes it's a tourist trap, but the beer is great and the atmosphere is always festive.  Our own Hofbrauhaus on the South Side is remarkably similar to its German cousin.  The menu is somewhat Americanized but the beer is pure Munich.  Located along the beautiful Mon river trail, close to the new marina, it has become a walking destination for us, especially when the biergarten is open.  My personal favorites are the Oktoberfest beer in season (one of the few beers imported from Germany rather than brewed on the premises) and the schnitzel Holsteiner style (topped with a fried egg).

Came here in April and tried their April tap called "hopfen spezial". It's exceptional- great crisp taste on a sunny hot day. The service is great and all the waitresses are very friendly. I'd come back.

This is one of my favorite places to hit with the guys when I'm in the PGH. The brew is not half bad and the food keeps me satisfied. My only complaint is that this place can get really busy on the weekends and you have to pay for parking in a nearby garage.

I am German and was looking forward to the Hofbräuhaus food. What a huge disappointment!! The food there doesn't even come close to German food! It was just a thrown together of what someone thought was German. Bah!! It was disgusting! The only good thing was the beer. I advise everyone who wants to try authentic German food to not go to this place. German food is so very much better than that crap!
Just isn't German enough to get more stars from me.  if it weren't for the really big and good beers, I would not keep going back for more...

I have been here several times to enjoy the beer and music, but hadn't eaten here until recently. I was pleasantly surprised! We started with the pretzels and bier cheese. In general I am not a bug pretzel fan but these were great. And the cheese sauce was AMAZING - I would have eaten it with a soon if I had one. For my entrée I had the Wurstplatte, which is a sampler of the bierwurst, bratwurst, and frankfurter. The food in general is pretty heavy, but I still managed to clean my plate. The wursts were very good, and the sides of mashed potatoes and sauerkraut were delicious.  This is not the kind of place I could be a regular at, but it is definitely a great spot to enjoy every so often, and it is great for groups. While the music can be pretty loud, there are enough tables further back that you can still partake in the fun while enjoying conversation at the same time.

I probably would have rated this higher before I ate hofbrahaus in Germany. The food doesn't compare but is still good. Love the beer garden. Be prepared to fight for a table in the beer hall. And if you like a nice quiet atmosphere, this isn't the place for you! Something fun you should experience in Pittsburgh.

This restaurant was amazing!  First, the prices were great.  We were a bit taken aback when the bill arrived, but approximately 12.00 for a lunch buffet was a great price and the drinks were fair too.  The food itself, for a buffet was excellent!  Very German and I would highly recommend the mashed potatoes and the sauerkraut!    Our waitress was prompt and attentive and kept a close check on us.  The entire atmosphere was very, very German, which lent to the entire experience!  As I said, we were there for lunch, so it wasn't crowded and I can't speak to the dinner time activities, but I would definitely eat here again!

Had a great time tonight. Justin was a great server. He's funny and very personable. We ordered a couple of beers. I enjoyed the Pittsburgh seasonal. The works appetizer was very good (I don't like sauerkraut but still found it good). We ordered our dinner to go which they had no problem with. We ate at our hotel next door and the food was amazing. They also had live music and my advice is not to go to the quiet dinning room but into the beer garden.

I always can fall for places that have good brews/drinks, any apps that have cheesy dips (pretzels are a must) and hearty entrees in a cozy or casual setting. Hofbrauhhaus has all my weaknesses in one spot. It's not too far off like the original in Munich, Germany.

Food was awesome. Ambience was like Oktoberfest. Large beer selection with a friendly, knowledgeable staff. It is loud so not a great a place for a quiet dinner but if you are looking for authentic German food in a fun atmosphere then this is the place to go in Pittsburgh

Best way to start a Sunday is drinking beer while watching football. The Hofbrau Haus has multiple tv a so that you can watch from any corner of the room. They don't have many beers on draft, but they do have monthly beer specials and you can guarantee to find German beer here (go figure!). Service is dressed in something that resembles traditional German dress and are very friendly.   All I have to say about the food, though, is I've had better. We found out the pirogies are microwaved Mrs. Ts that anyone could buy at the grocery store. This makes me question everything else we ate there. We're the bratwurst Johnsonville? The French fries Oreda? Should I just go to the nearest Giant Eagle and make my meal myself?  The answer in this case is yes.   Good beer, microwaved food, in the future I'll just travel to Munich so I don't feel like I'm completely ripping off a culture.

Hafbrauhaus is a lovely large brewery that sits on the river near the southside works.  They have a huge, and I mean huge beer hall that is very similar to the one in Munich.  The outdoor seating is awesome, and definitely my favorite part of the restaurant.  I'm not a beer far, and to be honest I go here often because DH is a beer connoisseur.  However I do love the beer here, and I don't feel bad that I can't sip down a nice glass of Merlot.  The food is just OK in my opinion, but then again I don't love eating large plates of sausage and meats.  The atmosphere is what redeems this place in my eye and it's awesome.  They always have live music and livelier people.  It's totally kosher to get smashed, dance on the tables, and belt your lungs out like a complete idiot...which I love.  Definitely check out this place for a good time.

If you don't like rowdy, this isn't the place for you. We waited an hour on a Saturday evening, which we expected so it wasn't a big deal. When moving to our seats we squeezed through a tight hallway past numerous staff and customers wandering around with beers. It was -loud- but fun loud. I ordered a Hefeweizen to drink and was very satisfied - easily one of the tastiest beers I've ever had. It had a light fruity aftertaste which I loved.   We got the works sampler for an appetizer and everything on it was A+. The bier cheese was sooooo good, and I didn't want to share any of the potato pancakes. We also ordered the pierogie which came on a bed of fried cabbage with bacon and loaded with chives and onion tanglers and was amazing. For my entree I got the Wurstplatte; all three sausages were delicious, and the mashed potatoes and sauerkraut were perfect accompaniment. Best kraut I've ever had by a long shot.   Service was upbeat and attentive, definitely a great experience.

Delicious!!!  I ate pretty much the entire menu with my friends there.  Spaetzle was awesome!!!  Wienerschnitzel with the fried egg on top....amazing...  Service was excellent and the food and drink were great.  It was hilarious watching these old high school group of friends (probably in their 40s or so and were probably Pittsburgh lifers) doing shotskis and drinking up a storm and then we got to see boobs as one of them flashed the entire room.  It was hilarious and so cute because you could tell they had been friends for god knows how long and  truly loved Pittsburgh.  It's nice to see that kind of unquestionable dedication.    And old boobs.  LMAO!
My husband LOVES this place. Beer selection is great. Service is always great. Food is superb! Music is great to listen to.

I happen to love the Hofbrauhaus. I bring my family and friends here every time they come into town.   Some people like to hate on the haus because it's food isn't super authentic and it's clientele is often frat-tastic, popped collars and all. I look beyond that and see the good beer served in giant mugs, guys dressed in lederhosen playing music, and in my opinion very good food.  Beer: Hofbrauhaus only servers their own beers to you only have a choice of their 4 main beers the Lager, Light Lager, Hefeweizen, and Dunkel. They also have a different specialty beer every month so when you go back you have something different to try.  Food:  I happen to really like their food. I have had several of their dishes and have liked all of them. I have always received good service and the food quality and preparation has always been consistent.   What's not to like. You will have fun when you go here, end of story.
Amazing food! I got to try German potato salad for the first time and it was very good! A little pricey maybe but the large portions make up for that and then some! We'll be visiting again for sure!
Open until 11pm but close their kitchen at 9pm. From out of town and a local recommended it. Disappointed.

This place just took me by surprise. The ambience was outstanding. The staff were all dressed up and really friendly. The drinks and food were good. The place is not highly priced. I would highly recommend this place for a drink. Cheers!

First time visiting here. The food was excellent. The service was fantastic. Atmosphere was great. We will come back soon and bring more people with us. If you have a chance please stop in and visit and have a great time. Also, the beer is fantastic.

The Hofbrauhaus here in Pittsburgh is, in my opinion, the best one here in the states (we've been to all of them except Cincinnati). My husband is from Bavaria & it is our favorite German food in the burgh. They have an extensive menu with tons of mouth watering options. You're sure to find something you like. I'm even a vegetarian and have had plenty of options to choose from. Their veggie burger on a pretzel bun with beer cheese is delicious. The nachos without meat & the appetizer sampler (minus the sauerkraut balls) are also good meat-free options.   The atmosphere is so fun at the Hofbrauhaus. It's a great place to go with our son because he is often entertained with a live band. In the summer, be sure to get a seat outside in the beer garden for a great seat along the river.   Always had great service even when the servers are slammed.   Overall love this place.

I dug it, but definitely only the part OUTSIDE where the polka band and college kids shaking their asses on tables WEREN'T.  I was kind of disappointed by the soft pretzels:  They seemed like they came from a microwave and the cheese wasn't as flavorful as I excitedly thought it would be.  Maybe I expected too much?  My hefewiezen was GOOOOOOOODDDDDDDDDDDD to the point where I drank about 2.5 times as much as I should have.  The guy waiting on us was a complete angel-- I'd go INSANE if I had to wait on that many plastered barely legals on a regular basis, but he seemed genuinely unbothered.

This is a weird place. I went with my brother and sister in law over Christmas and our friends didn't know they had to reserve a table beforehand. We put out name on the list and stood around drinking, singing with the band, going to the patio for those who smoked, and closed the place but never did get a table. Never ever. No table for us, so no food ordered or paid for. Just beer. I was glad they cut you off after so many beers, because one of our party had gotten her hands on an extra one after she was cut off and thrown out. (She needed to be thrown out.) But then she broke her leg out front. Crazy night, and I would've liked to try the food but won't be back. Once was enough.

Went here for the first time yesterday instead of Max's on North Side.  The open dining area felt like an authentic German hall sort of thing -- kind of like what I would imagine the German hall at Busch Gardens in Williamsburg would be like.    Service was pretty good.  For an appetizer, we got pretzels and bier cheese.  It was pretty tasty, but the bier cheese was kind of dry and stuck to the roof of my mouth (but it was totally worth it).  Ordered the schnitzel cordon bleu, which is fried veal, ham, and bier cheese on top, and for sides I substituted with a potato pancake and sauerkraut.  The food was really good and fresh, although the bier cheese was still pretty dry (maybe that's how it's supposed to be, I don't know.)  Overall, I had a pretty good experience here at the Hofbrauhaus, although I would still choose Max's over it.
